title: schools should ditch autumn exam plans
story: Repeat exams for kids who missed out on GCSEs and A levels this summer were due to take place in October for students unhappy with their grades this summer.But the NAHT union has called it “completely unreasonable” given the challenge of getting all pupils back to class for the next academic year.As some year  and  studentsto school they warn there is “no quick fix” to the damage done by the closures, as the government is set to announce more details on summer catch up schools this week.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leaders’ union NAHT called for the government to deliver a “detailed, coherent plan for September.He said: “It is vital that schools can focus on what is needed for their current students whether that is a phased reopening, improving remote learning or face to face teaching.“The proposal that all secondary schools will run an additional exam series in the autumn term is completely unreasonable in these circumstances.”Rubbishing the plan for summer catch up schools, he added: “Instead, we need a sustainable, long-term plan that draws on the wealth of knowledge within the profession about how to narrow achievement gaps, and serious consideration of a ‘catch-up premium’ to allow schools to focus on activities that are proven to work.”Amanda Spielman, Ofsted chief inspector, said many schools were being creative to help manage their class sizes and said dropping the two metre social distancing rule would mean more kids can go back to school.When asked whether reducing the two-metre social distancing guidelines would help schools accept more pupils, Ms Spielman said schools had been told there is a hierarchy of infection control, with handwashing placed higher than social distancing.She said: Social distancing within the bubbles of the half-size classes is, according to the guidance, an aspiration, not an absolute requirement.Whats really important is that everybody works to the guidance as it stands, plans for the relaxations that are likely to come along in future.But, yes, obviously, a reduced distance expectation will flow through into greater capacity in schools but what we need to get to is that plan for how we build capacity over time.Use relaxations as they come through but concentrate on the main objective which should surely be to get as many children back into school as possible and as soon as possible.Former Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair signed a letter calling for school kids on free school meals to get free internet at home.The proposal has been signed by over  MPs, former ministers and experts.Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh said: “The lockdown has exposed the digital ide in our society, with schools across the country reporting struggling families who do not have internet access at home.Those children who can’t access the same resources as their classmates will find themselves even further behind when they finally . Some may never catch up.“This policy isn’t a silver bullet and can’t replace months of missed education. But it would make an immediate, tangible dference to families right across our country.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: child obesity soar pupils six months off coronavirus
story: Fears have been raised that a lack of exercise could lead to weight gain for many, with one in five pupils already obese by the time they leave primary school. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThis month has seen children in certain age groups beginning toto school after months away during the lockdown. The government had previously said it wanted all primary school children tofor a month before the summer holidays, but the plans have now been dropped. Almost ten million children aged from reception to year ten will now be off school for at least six months between March and September.Russell Viner is the head of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health and also serves on the Government’s Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies.“We need to get kids back to school as soon as we can for their health, he told the Mail. “Everybody in the nutritional world is concerned.“We talk endlessly about the risks of transmission of Covid, and that’s incredibly important, but it’s not the only thing.“The risk-balance equation for children is about the risks of not being in school and poor mental health, poor sleep and potentially lack of exercise and obesity.”Any impact on childrens weight will also be dficult to measure because the NHSs National Child Measurement programme, which monitors the height and weight of children in reception and year six, has been put on hold. Experts have previously found some evidence that childrens average weight tends to increase each year over the summer break, which is just six weeks long. Speaking on Wednesday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that plans for schools tobefore the summer break had been dropped because the viruss infection rate “is not quite down far enough to change the social distancing measures in schools”.Head teachers association had previously said the plans would not be practicably possible, while teaching unions had raised concerns about the safety of pupils and staff. Running schools safely could mean reducing class sizes by up to a half, and the government is now under pressure to lay out a comprehensive plan for how it intends to see all pupils back by September. title: madeleine mccann cops preparing to search old wells at german paedo christian bs portuguese lair
story: Earlier this month, it was reported cops were preparing to dig up land around two Portuguese lairs where Christian B lived near Praia da Luz.One home, a farmhouse, is just  minutes walk from the hotel where the three-year-old went missing  years ago. The single-storey farmhouse property is littered with abandoned wells and sits on a hillside with a footpath to the beach where she played.Portuguese police were said yesterday to be considering searching the abandoned wells.According to Portuguese newspaper Sol, the Judicial Policehas looked at the possibility Madeleines body could be in the wells. But Portuguese cops havent yet received a request from German authorities to search places frequented in the Algarve by Christian B, Sol reports.Christian B, , is in jail in Germany for drug dealing and is appealing a  conviction for a rape in .Another former home of Christian Bs is up in the hills above Praia da Luz on a secluded road surrounded by just a few other houses - a drive from there to the holiday club takes  minutes.In June , Scotland Yard detectives backed by a team of snfer dogs excavated scrubland around  yards from the farmhouse building, but unearthed no clues.The beauty spot is also well known to Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry McCann, who regularly jogged around Black Rock after launching their hunt for their daughter in Praia da Luz in May .A Portuguese source said: “Judicial Police have confirmed they have been approached by German authorities in connection with the case and they will undoubtedly be prepared to carry out fresh searches in the hope of giving the McCanns closure.“The obvious focus would be around the hillside former farm building and another property nearby with links to him.”Meanwhile, Christian Bs lawyers say he will refuse to answer questions because prosecutors must have proof he was involved in her disappearance, it is reported.Lawyer Friedrich Fulscher said: Mr B is remaining silent on the allegation at this time on the advice of his defence counsel. This is quite common in criminal proceedings.It is the duty of the state to prove that a suspect committed a crime. No accused person has to prove his innocence to the investigating authorities.A former German police chief has admitted it was a huge mistake to noty Christian B in  that he was a person of interest in Madeleines disappearance.Cops in Braunschweig sent Christian B a summons seven years ago to appear for questioning in relation to the Madeleine case,Der Spiegelreported last Friday.There are fears the alleged blunder could have allowed him to destroy any evidence that may have existed, experts told the German newspaper.Ulf Kuch, the former head of police in the German city of Braunschweig, said sending the letter was a huge mistake.Mr Kuch said he did not know about the Christian B summons despite his role at the time as supervisor for the officer who issued the notice, Thereported.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris no deal brexit talks
story: The Prime Minister is fighting to speed up the pace of Brexit negotiations as the head of the World Trade Organisation warned Britains recovery from COVID- could be hampered by no-deal. Mr Johnson will tell President of the European Council Charles Michel, President of the EU Commission Ursula von der Leyen and president of the European Parliament, David Sassoli, there needs to be a renewed energy and commitment in negotiations. But the PM is ready to threaten no-dealthere is no sign of progression in talks with the bloc, according to The Times.Last week Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove ruled out extending the transition period. But he agreed to a six-month delay before bringing in full border checks and collecting tarfs. The WTO has predicted that global trade could fall by a third because of the pandemic.WTO director-general Roberto Azevêdo warned the car industry and agriculture would be among the worst hit sectorsBritain didnt thrash out a deal with the bloc. The PM is expected to go to great s to protect jobs in the car industry in a speech to reboot the economy next month. One of the policies could offer Brits up to £, to trade in old diesel and petrols cars for electric cars in a bid to boost sales at companies such as Nissan who employ thousands at their Sunderland factory. But Mr Azevêdo said they would be subjected to heavy tarfsthe UK defaults to WTO trading rules under a no-deal Brexit. Mr Johnson wants a deal which gives Britain tarf-free access to EU markets but he has insisted the nation has nothing to fear by trading on WTO terms. The PM has stressed giving business certainty there will be no extension to the transition period with the EU - where the UK still has to follow the blocs rules - is more important. Mr Azevêdo told The Andrew Marr Show on BBC One WTO trade rules were not a catastrophe he said they “will impose a number of adjustments and those can be painful, particularly for some sectors”.He added: The less disruption the better, the less turbulence the better, and less turbulence is the closest to where you were before. Soyou can maintain the degree of integration and relationship that you had before Brexit, it is less traumatic thanyou have to go to WTO terms. The WTO boss thought there was a good chance the UK and EU would find a dealthere is political will to do so. He said: If people realise that a no-deal scenario is much less than optimal, Im pretty confident that negotiators could do this in a reasonable way with a reasonable time frame. A group of cross-party MPs are trying to get the Government to allow a vote on extending the transition period. title: commuters wear masks compulsory public transport coronavirus
story: Brits pulled on the face coverings as they got on trains and Tubes this morning to stop the spread of the deadly bug.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCommuters were this morning pictured at Waterloo station wearing masks as they headed back to work.British Transport Police will have the power to fine rule breakers £they fail to wear the safety precautions.And BTP today tweeted out a reminder to Brits to make sure they wear the masks - with the items being handed out at many stations to make sure people are following the rules.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced that from June  it will be mandatory for people to wear face coverings on public transport.This includes on trains, buses, trams, ferries and aircraft.Masking the mouth and nose reduces the risk of asymptomatic carriers — people who are infected but showing no symptoms — from passing on the bug.A DIY face-covering can be used — even just a scarf or a thin cloth mask.Railway staff will also adopt the mask-wearing guidelines.But the Government has warned that for face coverings to be effective, people must wash their hands before putting them on and taking them off.The government is asking people to use a simple face covering, and not buy up PPE standard medical masks as they still are needed for the NHS.Private hire taxis and minicabs are also included in the ­measures, but the rules do not cover bus stops, railway stations and other terminals.Anyone not wearing a mask will be kicked off unless they are disabled, young children or have breathing dficulties.Face coverings are now also compulsory in hospitals, with staff, visitors and outpatients required to wear them.Mr Shapps said that it would be an England-only rule, but he expects that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will follow suit.He said: You can be refused travelyou dont comply and you could be fined.The Department of Health said previously, after considering the latest scientic advice from SAGE, that face coverings can help reduce the spread of Covid-.They stressed that the evidence shows face coverings can stop you passing coronavirus on to others,you are asymptomatic or have yet to develop symptoms.A new German study last week showed that the compulsory use of facemasks slows the spread of coronavirus by  per cent.The study was able to use the staggered introduction of masks in shops and on public transport across Germany as a natural experiment to test how effective the masks were.Looking at the new cases in the days that followed the experiment, scientists found that there is “strong and convincing statistical support” that the masks “strongly reduced the number of incidences”. Scientists have even suggested that wearing face masks might protect against coronavirus better than handwashing or social distancing.But some scientists criticised the mandatory use of face masks on the grounds that there was still no evidence that masks helped stop the spread of the virus.Other groups argue that without strong evidence, there was a clear plausible mechanism for how even homemade cloth masks could stop onward transmission Measures drawn up under Theresa Mayaposs government to enable transgender people change their birth certicate without a medical diagnosis have been ditched by Mr Johnsonaposs No  team, according to The Sunday Times. Instead, the paper said ministers plan to announce a ban on gay cure therapies, in what was described as an attempt to placate LGBT people. At the same time, the Government was said to be preparing to set out new safeguards to protect female-only spaces - including refuges and public lavatories - to stop them being used by those with male anatomy. The details were said to be contained in a leaked paper setting out the Governmentaposs long-delayed response to a public consultation on the Gender Recognition Act. The Sunday Times said that the paper was basically ready and was being slated for publication by the equalities minister Liz Truss at the end of July before MPs break for the summer. A No  source told the PA news agency that the details of the response were yet to be finalised, and the Prime Minister would have the final say on the recommendations. According to The Sunday Times, around , responses to the public consultation were received - with around % in favour of allowing people to self-identy as a man or a woman. However, officials were said to believe that the results had been skewed by an avalanche of responses generated by trans rights groups. The paper quoted a source as saying: In terms of changing what is on your birth certicate, you will still need to have proper medical approval. And youaposre not going to be able to march in and find a hippie quack doctor who is willing to say youaposre a woman. Thataposs not going to happen.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNon-essential shops and zoos reopen from Monday  June in England as the economy slowly creaks back into le. For the first time in three months youaposll be able to go clothes shopping and see the lemurs. But there will be strict social distancing rules in place and firms will be ordered to carry out more hygiene measures than usual. Expect queues outside shops and high demand for tickets for attractions allowed to reopen. Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a bubble with one other household in England. This means breaking the two-metre rule for the first time to hug and kiss, share childcare, stay the night and have sexthataposs your thing. Hereaposs everything you need to know about the lockdown changes this week. Two separate households in England can now join together in a “support bubble” under certain conditions. They won’t need to follow the two-metre rule - meaning they can hug, kiss, share childcare and meals, hang out indoors, stay the night and even have sex for the first time since March . One of the two households in each bubble must be a “single-adult household”. This means either a person who lives alone, or a single parent who lives with children under . The other household they are joining with can be of any size, and can have more than one adult in it. However, in total each bubble must only consist of two households - and each household must keep the arrangement “exclusive”. That means a person living alone cannot form multiple bubbles with multiple households. Likewise, a family cannot form multiple bubbles with more than one lonely relative. For a full explanation and QA click here. What changes in England from June  Non-essential shops reopen  Non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen for the first time for almost three months in England. Stories will need strict social distancing measures, much like those weaposve already seen in supermarkets and other essential stores. Brands vowing to reopen bang on time from June  include Primark, GAME, Debenhams, O, EE and BT, HM, Lush, GAME, H Samuel and Argos. John Lewis is set to open most stores from June , while Next will open a handful followed by others in the coming weeks. Types of shop allowed to reopen include:Fashion shops Charity shops Betting shops and arcades Tailors, dress fitters and fashion designers Auction houses Antique stores Retail art galleries Photography studios Gt shops and retail spaces in theatres, museums, libraries, heritage sites and tourism sites Mobile phone stores Craft fairsFace coverings will be mandatory on public transport  Everyone travelling on public transport in England will be required to wear a face covering from June . Wearing a face covering - not a surgical mask - will be part of the conditions of carriage for travelling on public transport. That means travellers could be refused permission to board buses or trainsthey refuse to comply with the order. Serious offenders could be fined, but ministers have claimed people will largely comply and this wonapost be needed.  Hospital visitors and staff will need to wear face coverings and masks All hospital visitors and outpatients in England will be required to wear face coverings - while all hospital staff will be required to wear higher-grade, type  or  surgical masks. Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemasstart to re-open  Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemas are set to reopen in England from Monday. Boris Johnson has said they can reopen as long as they follow social distancing rules. That means their on-site cafes and restaurants are expected to operate as take-away only. Only outdoor attractions are allowed to reopen, so reptile houses and indoor aquariums will remain closed. Sites will be operating at reduced capacity, and there may be one-way systems in place. And of course, because very few things are likely to be open it will be busy, you should book your ticket online in advance to ensure youaposre not disappointed when you turn up. Churches reopen but only for private prayer  Places of worship reopen in England from June , but only for private prayer and not for services. Iniduals are expected to be able to reflect and pray while adhering to social-distancing rules - but worship groups, weddings and other services will still not be permitted. In line with government guidance churches will be expected to be deep-cleaned regularly and should remove shared books from public areas. Churches have been closed since  March, following instructions from the Government. School pupils in Years  and a quarter at a time  Secondary schools in England can reopen for Years  and  from June , but not all students will be allowed toat the same time. Only a quarter of eligible pupils will be allowed in school at any one time - meaning schools have had to instigate special timetables and classes to make the system work. Secondary schools are not likely to fully reopen until September at the earliest. Students who dowill be encouraged to travel separately and avoid public transport. The teaching of vulnerable children and those of critical workers in all year groups will continue until the start of the summer holidays. Some primary schools will open a bit further than they are now While around half of the UKaposs primary schools have been open to more pupils from June , some have remained closed to all but key workersapos kids. This meant nursery, reception, year one and year six pupils in some parts of the country havenapost yet got back into the classroom. Some places, like Doncaster and Liverpool, stopped schools reopening on June , but will see them reopening their doors on Monday. Donapost expect more big changes to primary school attendance before September though. Plans for all pupils in Years , ,  and  tofor a month before the summer break in England have been dropped by Education Secretary Gavin Williamson. Instead schools are just being asked to bring back whoever they can, depending on capacity. He told MPs he is now aiming to get all children back to school in September,possible. What has already changed in recent weeks in EnglandJune : Primary schools were asked to reopen to years R,  and  in England - though only about half of them actually did June : People allowed to meet in socially-distanced groups of up to  outdoors, including in private gardens June : Car showrooms and outdoor markets allowed to reopen June : Dentists begin to reopen with extra hygiene measures in place June : -day quarantine comes into forced for those arriving in the UK June : Some parking charges that were suspended . What weaposll still need to wait until July for - or longer Pubs, restaurants and bars Pubs, restaurants, bars and cafes are not expected to reopen in England until July  at the earliest. They can already operate as takeaways - good news for pubs next to parks or beaches - but they canapost have people drinking on the premises, even in the beer garden. Pubs arenapost guaranteed to reopen on July  - thataposs just the starting date for the hospitality and leisure industry so boozers might come later. When they do open itaposll have to be with social distancing rules in place. Hairdressers and nail bars  Hairdressers, barbers and beauty salons are also only opening from July  at the earliest. And like pubs, the date could end up being later because itaposs hard to avoid being in close contact with someone cutting your hair. The two-metre rule Boris Johnson is under pressure to drop the two-metre social distancing rule down to one metre or one and a half. This would increase the risk of catching the virus from someone but allow the economy to restart. The government has made clear that the two-metre rule is still in all its guidance, including draft rules for pubs and cafes to reopen. But that could change in future. Boris Johnson has said he wants to cut the distance but only when itaposs supported by the science. In basic terms, that means waiting until your overall risk from catching the virus in wider society is so low, some extra risk from the person youaposre next to is acceptable. Scientists say youaposre  to  times more at risk from one metre away than two metres away. Wider school reopenings

It is feared the PM will do everything to avoid it because he knows it will reveal how he mishandled the pandemic. But he has been told lessons from his mistakes must be learnedlives are to be saved in a new peak feared in September. Emma Norris, of the Institute for Government, said: “A rapid review is essential to be better prepared. The Government must learn lessons nowit is to make adjustments and help save lives in the event of a second wave. “This exercise should be launched as soon as possible, reporting by early autumn and sharing findings with the public.” And she says the  should be made up of public health experts, epidemiologists and Whitehall officials, with an independent chair. It would look at PPE failures, test and trace fiasco, care home disasters and how lockdown is being lted. The PM has refused calls for an immediate inquiry, saying although there will be a time to learn lessons he’s been “very proud” of pandemic handling.He also rejected any probe into aide Dominic Cummings who flouted lockdown by driving  miles to Durham. Pandemic predictor Professor Neil Ferguson said the “R” transmission rate needs to be below . to avert a second wave. It currently averages . but the position is “unclear” going forward. That’s why Nightingale hospitals have been put on ice rather than closed down. Professor Ferguson, of Imperial College London, added: “We have a little bit of wiggle room, but it will be a learning experience as to how we allow society to resume while maintaining control of transmission.” An inquiry would also answer the question of whether two-metre social distancing can be reduced to one – a move the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies says is dodgy.  UK chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said: “A minute at two metres contact is about the same risk as six seconds at one.” The UK has the second-highest death rate of any major country in the world with  per million of population, behind Belgium’s . Nearly , are known to have been infected and , have died in care homes. By September local authority providers will face a £.billion bill including £billion on PPE, £billion on staff and £million on deep cleaning. But the Government has only provided half the social care funding needed.  The spread of the virus has been blamed on a failure to test early. At the height of the pandemic the UK conducted . tests per , people compared to Italy’s ., Ireland’s  and Germany’s .. Relaxing lockdown rules could prompt a second virus surge by the end of August “that is higher and lasts longer than the first”, says mathematician Dr David Glass, of Ulster University.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDevastating pet camera footage showing a lonely cat aposcryingapos and searching for his owner with a lead in his mouth has gone viral. Ida Myrinaposs cat Isola appeared so distraught after being left at home for just  minutes she now feels she can never leave him alone again. A Reddit post containing the video has been upvoted more than , times since it was shared last month with many viewers commenting on how disturbing the behaviour is. The cat owner, from Varmland, Sweden, said the longer she watched the clip, the more distressing it became, despite initially thinking it was cute.  “We thought it was pretty cute at first but when we noticed that he didnapost stop it just felt sad, Ida told the Daily Star.“He talks a lot with that ‘whiny’ and sad voice and tone so itaposs hard to tell [ he’s crying]. “But he also hates being alone tho, so maybe he is crying.” She added that Isola “seemed so lonely and restless”.  “It felt like we never could leave him alone again,” Ida - editor of newspaper Nya Wemlands-Tidningen - added. The footage shows the cute kitty patrolling the hallway apparently trying to find his owner. With a lead in his mouth, Isola looks even more desperate to not be left alone. The cat then starts meowing in what hundreds of Reddit viewers believe was a form of “crying”. “Oh that mournful sound,” one viewer commented. Another devastated user wrote: “This made me cry a little.” And a third added: “This is devastating to watch.”To keep up to date with Isola’s activities, follow Ida’s Instagram page  @idamyrin.

England from today after  weeks of being shut in lockdown. Major names set to open some of their stores include Apple, Argos, Curryaposs, PC World, HM, House of Fraser and Lush. The Prime Minister announced on Monday  May that all non-essential retailers in England will be allowed to open with social distancing in place from  June. Business Secretary Alok Sharma said it was the latest step in reopening Britainaposs economy. Any business reopening must demonstrate that it is compliant to customers and businesses who failed to comply by the rules would face harsh penalties. Shops planning to reopen such as Marks  Spencer and Ikea said ahead of the reopening that they will impose restrictions on the number of customers entering their stores. For more of the latest updates throughout today, follow our LIVE blog, below to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening. Key EventsFace coverings must be worn on public transport from today::First easyJet flight departs Liverpool John Lennon Airport in  weeksEasyJet#xs first flight from Liverpool John Lennon Airport has departed after an -week hiatus.The flight to Belfast left Liverpool at .am and is scheduled to arrive at .am.EasyJet told the Liverpool Echo the cabin is thoroughly disinfected daily providing surface protection from viruses for at least  hours.:Primarks Covid-ready safety measuresLiverpool Echo reporter Elle May Rice, who was down at the city centre Primark store for the reopening, said: #xCThere are barriers as you come in as well so it#xs one way in, one way out. #xCStock is much more spaced out than usual too.#xDThe safety measures Primark has taken include:Extra security - Extra security staff will be added to the team to help with a queuing system and to make sure people are following the rules.Warning signs - Signs will be put around the shops and on the floor to explain the rules.Emptier aisles - The number of customers allowed in the store at any time will be limited. By having fewer people in the store, both shoppers and staff will be able to stay a safe distance away from each other.Tills closed - Primark will only reopen every other till, meaning there is extra staff being staff working behind the counter and customers paying.PPE - All staff will be available to every member of staff who wants to wear one.Sanitiser - There will also be hand sanitiser stations at the front of every store, so customers can wash their hands as they arrive.Screens - Perspex screens have been put in front of the tills.More cleaners - All shops will be cleaned more often during the day, with particular focus on #xtouch points#x - including tills, escalators and lts. They will also do extra cleaning of staff areas.Primark in Liverpool City centre :Homeless cancer survivor, , forced to live on sons driveway for two yearsA homeless elderly couple are begging for a home after spending two years living in a cramped campervan on their son#xs driveway.The Birmingham couple have told how they have been forced to live in the situation for two years.Philip Higgs, , and we Pamela, , are now appealing to Birmingham City Council to help them find proper accommodation after enduring the coronavirus lockdown in the van.Click here to read their story.The couple have lived in the campervan for two years :Reducing social distancing to m would result in increase in riskDr Michael Tildesley, infectious disease scientist at the University of Warwick, said reducing the social distancing restriction from two metres to one #xCwill result in an increase in risk#xD. The Government#xs two-metre rule is currently under review, as ministers balance public health priorities with enabling more businesses to reopen. Speaking on BBC Breakfast on Monday, Dr Tildesley said: #xCThe evidence is still slightly unclear - depending upon the studies it could be anything from about twice the risk to  times the risk. #xCSo there is an increase in risk with going down to one metre. #xCBut I have to stress this is purely based upon public health, and the Government has to consider economic factors before taking a decision.#xD:Shoppers trying to look through Primark windows to see which products in stockIn Wolverhampton, shoppers tweeted crowds of more than  by am this morning, while in Liverpool, crowds are already being allowed inside.In Hull, it#xs similar scenes, though the city centre store won#xt be allowing crowds inside until am.#xCMany shoppers are trying to look through the windows to see which products are in stock at Primark,#xD one shopper tweeted.:Huge queues already seen outside PrimarkHuge queues are already gathering outside Primark stores across England as the chain prepares to reopen for the first time since March .Crowds of shoppers have been pictured outside the chain#xs Birmingham flagship branch - which will today welcome shoppers for the first time in three months, following a lockdown that has cost the business #xA.billion.A total of  stores will reopen to the public - with two metre social distancing and one-way queues in place.Other measures include extra security staff, safety signs and revised hours as the chain slowly reopens for business.However, in line with Government guidelines, staff and customers will not be required to wear PPE or face coverings inside stores.On entry, there will be blue bubbles all floors, reminding people to stay two metres apart as they are wait in line.Every branch will also have a separate entrance and exit, with marshals on hand to keep count of how many customers come in and out.Basket handles will be cleaned after every use and customers will be asked to use a contactless hand sanitising unit.Click here for the full story. Queues of shoppers waiting for the opening of Primarks Flagship store in Birmingham :Volunteers hand out masks to commuters in LondonVolunteers handed out blue masks to commuters as they entered and left Vauxhall Underground station in London, where two security guards were stationed to stop people taking more masks than necessary. A team of five volunteers were in place in the ticket hall from .am. The majority of those travelling wore a face covering while a handful picked up a free mask, which were laid out on two tables. Two British Transport Police officers stood near the ticket gates monitoring those travelling up on the escalators.Commuters at Victoria Station in London :Some of the shops reopening todaySome of the non-essential shops set to reopen today include Currys PC World which will open  stores.Debenhams will reopen  of their stores in England. HM is planning to open #xCthe majority#xD of its stores in England on Monday, although it wouldn#xt confirm exact numbers and fitting rooms will stay closed.:Commuters head to work with face coveringsCommuters have been pictured heading to work wearing face coverings. As of today, people must wear face coverings on public transport in England.Below is a photo of commuters at Waterloo Station in London on the first morning since the new rules came in. Commuters at Waterloo station, London :Strictly pros to isolate together for two weeks so they can shoot group dancesStrictly Come Dancing professionals are reportedly planning to isolate together so that they can film group dances together.The show#xs producers are looking at ways of ensuring the BBC has a Strictly series this year despite the coronavirus pandemic leading to social distancing and other restrictions.So that the show goes on, The Sun has reported that isolating the pro dancers in a hotel for two weeks would mean that group dances could be filmed and used throughout the series.Click here for the story in full. :EastEnders filming begins again with stars social distancing in scenesWalford is coming to le again as the cameras start rolling on the EastEnders set after its enforced shutdown due to the coronavirus lockdown.In the first pics of the new scenes being filmed, Danny Dyer can be seen social distancing from Kellie Bright as they show how le in Albert Square will change.Danny, as Mick Carter, and Kellie as his on-screen we Linda Carter can be seen outside the Queen Vic pub with the coronavirus protocols in place.Cast and crew have ed to Elstree Studios in Borehamwood, Hertfordshire for the first episodes since the lockdown, with the hope that the BBC soap will be back on TV by September, though this has not been confirmed yet by the Beeb.Click here for the story. Kellie Bright and Danny Dyer social distancing in new EastEnders scenes :Coronavirus resurgence in Beijing promptsof tough measuresBeijing reported its second consecutive day of record new numbers of COVID- cases on Monday, adding urgency to efforts to rein in a sudden resurgence of the coronavirus in the Chinese capital.The recent outbreak has been traced to a major wholesale food market, Xinfadi, which accounts for % of Beijing#xs farm produce supply sourced both domestically and from overseas. The market has been shut, tens of thousands of nearby residents are being tested for the virus and a city-wide campaign launched to identy people who have recently visited the market or have been in contact with people who have.:Hong Kongs Disneyland to reopen on June Hong Kong#xs Disneyland theme park said on Monday it will reopen on June  to a reduced number of visitors and with enhanced health measures after the coronavirus outbreak forced it to close in late January. The city has reported only a handful of new cases recently, with its total so far standing at , infections and four deaths. The majority of the park#xs shopping and dining locations will restart operations with #xCcontrolled capacity,#xD while social distancing measures will be implemented in queues, restaurants and other facilities. Hotel services will also resume gradually. Disinfection will be carried out more frequently and hand sanitisers will be made available for visitors, who will be required to go through temperature screening, wear a face mask and sign a health declaration.:Germanys confirmed coronavirus cases rise by  to ,The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Germany increased by  to ,, data from the Robert Koch Institutefor infectious diseases showed on Monday. The reported death toll rose by four to ,, the tally showed.:Thailand reports no new coronavirus cases and no new deathsThailand has reported no new coronavirus infections or deaths today. It has had a total of , confirmed cases and  fatalities. It is the second time in five days that no cases were reported and marked  days without a local transmission. There are , patients who have recovered. All recent cases have been found in quarantine among Thais ing from abroad, said Taweesin Wisanuyothin, a spokesman for the government#xs COVID- task force.:KEY EVENTFace coverings must be worn on public transport from todayBrits could be fined up to #xAthey are don#xt wear a face mask on public transport from today.The Government has made it law to wear them on all trains, buses, trams, ferries and aircraft in a bid to reduce the spread of coronavirus.Covering the mouth and nose like this cuts the risk of asymptomatic carriers - people who are infected but showing no symptoms - from passing on the virus.DIY face coverings can be used, even scarves or thin cloth masks.Railway staff will also have to follow the new rule.British Transport Police can fine those not wearing masks #xA on the spot.A commuter wearing a face covering at Victoria Station in London this morning :Worldwide coronavirus cases cross . millionMore than . million people have been reported to be infected by coronavirus globally. According to a Reuters tally, , have died. Infections have been reported in more than  countries and territories since the first cases were identied in China in December .:Businesses that are banned from reopening todayLibraries, churches, cinemas and galleries are just a handful of outlets that won#xt be allowed to reopen this month, despite the Government giving clothing retailers the green light from Monday.Many small and large scale businesses have been told they won#xt be able to trade until at least July , in a move that could place many already struggling firms on the brink of collapse.Clothing retailers, charity shops and mobile phone stores will be able to open again from June  - providing they are #xCCovid-#x ready.Click here to .:Some of the shops set to reopen from today!A whole host of shops are allowed to open their doors to the public again as rules are relaxed.But it won#xt quite be business as usual, with new rules brought in to ensure people shopping in person can be kept as safe as possible.That means, while technically allowed to open, several chains - and a string of independent shops - have decided to stay closed for now.Others, such as Next and John Lewis, have decided that while it#xs safe to open some branches, others will stay closed for a bit longer.But that doesn#xt mean there won#xt be more choice than at any point since March.Major names set to open some of their stores include Apple, Argos, Curry#xs, PC World, HM, House of Fraser and Lush.Apple - all  stores in England and Northern Ireland - customers will have their temperature checked and be required to wear masks while visiting, although the chain will provide theseneededArgos -  stand alone stores - Argos branches inside Sainsbury#xs have been operating for most of lockdown, but the chain#xs stand alone stores have been closed. That ends on Monday with  branches reopening. You can use the Argos store locator to get updates on your nearest branch.Click our full story to see more.More OnCoronavirus

One woman, who was cycling alone when she was targeted by the ten-strong gang, has spoken out about her ordeal in order to raise awareness of the aposcanal pusherapos gang. Sophie Watson, , said she was attacked by a teenage gang as she rode home to the Jewellery Quarter on the Worcester and Birmingham Canal on Friday evening, June . As she was left bruised and soaking, she came across another woman who appeared to have suffered the same attack.Speaking to BirminghamLive, Sophie said at least five women had been targeted along the canal on the same night.While only one incident has been reported to the police, officers have increased their foot patrols along the canal route. Sophie reported what happened to her, but said there were no witnesses to her attack as the stretch of canal had been quiet at the time. I was coming from the university towards the city centre, along the canal, when I saw around ten boys on bikes shouting between them, she said. I squeezed past - I was right next to the canal - and one of them nudged me in. They just cycled on towards Stirchley, laughing. There was no-one around to call for help so I climbed out and headed on home. But a little further down the canal I saw another woman - roughly the same age as me - being helped out of the water. Two men had stopped to help her. Sheaposd been pushed in too. Sophie later tweeted about her experience and has since heard about other women being pushed in to the canal near Bournville, also on Friday night. I cycle this route most days and had just been out for a bit of exercise. Iaposd travelled down cycle route five to Stichley, then back along the canal, she said. I always wondered when Iaposd end up falling in, I never expected Iaposd be pushed in. People have since contacted me to say they knew of others who had been pushed in around Bournville last night. It was a shock but my biggest worry is that it will deter women from cycling, she added. Iaposll continue to cycle but will steer clear of the canal for a while. The yobs who targeted Ms Watson as she was cycling were said to have been aged between  and . A statement from West Midlands Police read: We were called to reports of a woman cyclist being pushed into a canal near Carver Street, Birmingham just after .pm on Friday evening.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe man charged after urinating by murdered PC Keith Palmeraposs memorial has been labelled a plonker by his own dad. David Banks told The Sun that son Andy, , must have become desperate with all public toilets closed during protests in central London - but had not aimed at the memorial. A photo of Banks in Parliament Square showing a line of urine running behind him has caused outrage due to the fact the memorial was for PC Palmer who was stabbed to death in the  terror attack in Westminster. Violence erupted over the weekend as a far-right demonstration took place after thousands of anti-racism protesters had marched on previous weekends sparked by the death of George Floyd in the US.  Mr Floydaposs death has prompted weeks of discussion and outrage about racism and colonialism in the UK. Mr Banks said his son is not a member of EDL and he would kill himhe joined the far-right group. “Sometimes young lads get a bit desperate. Andy picked a stupid place to go to the toilet,” said the dad. “He’s devastated. He can apologise for being a stupid plonker.  “He was next to it, not on it. All the toilets were closed. Its a silly thing to go and urinate on a public street. “But he’s not the first person to have done that and I don’t suppose he’ll be the last.” Mr Banks said his son had never been in trouble with the police before. On Sunday evening, Scotland Yard said Banks, from Stansted, Essex, had been charged with outraging public decency and remains in custody. The act was widely condemned by politicians including MP Tobias Ellwood, who gave first aid to PC Palmer as he lay dying after being stabbed to death in the grounds of Parliament by Khalid Masood.  Boris Johnson has announced plans for a cross-government commission to examine all aspects of racial inequality in Britain in the wake of two weeks of Black Lives Matter protests. Writing in The Daily , the Prime Minister acknowledged that the country had much more to do to deal with the issue. He said the commission on race and ethnic disparities would look at all aspects of inequality - in employment, in health outcomes, in academic and all other walks of le. Mr Johnson told broadcasters: What I really want to do as Prime Minister is change the narrative so we stop the sense of victimisation and discrimination.  We stamp out racism and we start to have a real expectation of success. Thataposs where I want to get to but it wonapost be easy. The Prime Ministeraposs announcement comes after a statue of Winston Churchill in Parliament Square was boarded up due to vandalism during an anti-racist protest. Members of Saturdayaposs far-right demonstration, which was attended by several hundred mostly white men, claimed to be guarding the statue of Churchill as well as the cenotaph. However, the event turned violent after hundreds of self-proclaimed statue defenders took over areas near the Houses of Parliament and Trafalgar Square and hurled missiles, smoke grenades, glass bottles and flares at police officers. A total of  people were arrested and the protest was condemned by Boris Johnson as racist thuggery and described as mindless hooliganism by police.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters are making a fresh push to get more primary children back to school, amid warnings the poorest kids are being left behind by a lack of support in lockdown. Heads are expected to be told they can bring back one extra year groupthey have the capacity to maintain classes of just  pupils. But there will be no extra funding for more teachers or alternative ­premises, such as Portakabins or local community halls. And the Government was accused of failing to back hundreds of ­thousands of disadvantaged kids who do not have proper access to computers or the internet and who may struggle with schoolwork. In the most deprived schools, % of teachers report more than a third of students would not have had use of a device for home learning over the  weeks of lockdown so far. The Government promised , free laptops as part of a £million scheme to help narrow the digital ide – but last week Education Secretary Gavin Williamson admitted just half of those have arrived. The UK coronavirus death toll yesterday rose by  to , – and some experts have warned against children going back to school. But there were growing calls on ministers to address the growing fears for disadvantaged children kept home as research revealed their learning is most likely to suffer. Former PM Tony Blair, ex-chief inspector of schools Sir Michael Wilshaw, four former education ­secretaries, cross-party MPs, teaching unions and charities are among ­signatories to a letter to ministers warning of the risk to education.  The letter says: “This leline has not been available for all, with schools across the country reporting ­struggling families who do not have internet access at home. “Those children who can’t access the same resources as their ­classmates will find themselves even further behind when theyto school. “There is a risk that some may never catch up.” With growing frustration among teachers, MPs and unions over the chaoticof schools, Children’s Commissioner for England, Anne Longfield, warned the right to ­a ­guaranteed education was under threat. She said: “It has taken  years of campaigning to get children into the classroom, ensuring that education was a basic right for all.  “We seem for the first time to be prepared to let that start to go into reverse. And I think that is a very, very dangerous place to be. “We heard from the Prime Minister back in April that education was one of the top three priorities for easing lockdown, but it seems to have been given up on quite easily.” The Government will today come under pressure to provide laptops and internet access to the homes of the most vulnerable children to help them catch up. Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh is presenting a Bill in Parliament calling for all ­children eligible for free school meals to have a broadband ­connection and internet at home. Ministers have also been stung by ­accusations they have put retail ahead of education – especially that of the most deprived – as ­non-essential shops start to reopen today. There are at least , ­disadvantaged children who do not have access to devices Primaries have reopened to Reception classes, Year One and Year Six. Under the push to get more back, it is thought schools may be able to take Year Five pupils,schools can limit the numbers to . Although secondary years  and  will start to go back from today, millions more will not be back before September at the earliest.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum discovered a secret tip hidden behind her living room wallpaper while she was re-decorating. Charlotte Morrison and partner Yariden were stripping the old layers of wallpaper in their London home when they discovered the message left on the wall in . After posting her find on social media - and accumulating thousands of shares - she eventually got in touch with the previous homeowner.“If you ever need to re-wallpaper this room again it will take  rolls of wallpaper, the note read, reports the Daily Star.“I bought just six rolls at £. per roll, I didn’t have enough, .” The note was signed off by a man named “Jon” and with the date “st December ”.Taking a snap of the uncovered message, Charlotte uploaded it to Facebook – with the image quickly going viral and clocking up over , likes and , shares.She wrote alongside the image: “So decided to strip all the wallpaper layers finally in the front room, come across this. Cheers Jon.” An update the following week revealed the London based mum-of-two revealed she had tracked down the mystery author. She wrote: “WE FOUND JON!! “A relative of Jon’s contacted me! Described our house and correct address. “Only Jon hates social media, instead of statuses he writes notes. I let Jon’s relative know that social media thinks he’s a legend.” One friend suggested the message was too good to ever cover up. They suggested: “Please put a little frame around his message and paint or wallpaper all around it!”

The Duke of York, , is hoping he will be able to resume his senior royal duties, according to the Sunday Times. But the Queenaposs patience with her embattled son is aposwearing thinapos after he got himself into yet another public scrap over the FBIaposs investigation into Epstein, a source told the newspaper. Buckingham Palace is aposfuriousapos with the Duke of York after he rowed with US investigators probing the American billionaire, who died in jail awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Courtiers are accusing the dukeaposs statement to investigators who have requested to quiz him of overshadowing his fatheraposs birthday celebrations.  Prince Philipaposs th birthday was hoped to be a positive moment for the troubled monarchy, but it came in the same week Andrew dominated headlines once again as he slammed US investigators. A source close to the duke told the newspaper the duke regretted the fallout over his disastrous interview with the BBCaposs Emily Maitlis. He had described the widely-mocked interview as a apossuccessapos - but is now said to have expressed regret he failed to apologise to Epsteinaposs victims. The Duke has faced humiliation over his response to questions about his links to disgraced Epstein. The Sunday Times reports today he will refuse to co-operate with the request of US investigators that he travel to the States to help with their inquiries until he gets an aposolive branchapos. In the Newsnight interview he denied having sex with Epstein accuser Virginia Giuffre, now Roberts, on three occasions. Giuffre has claimed in US court she was flown across the world by Epstein, including once, in March , to have sex in London with the prince, who has denied her allegation.  The source told the Sunday Times: I donapost think he regrets the intention behind the interview, which was to clear the air for his family, the royal family and the institution. But the fact he was unable to appropriately or sufficiently convey his sympathy for the victims of Epstein, is of course a source of regret. Prince Andrewaposs handling of the saga was said to have dismayed senior Palace courtiers. But palace officials were said to be fuming anew after he publicly locked horns with the US Department of Justicein a fresh row last week. The DOJ has filed a Mutual Legal Assistance request to the British government in a bid to force the prince to supply a statement. He issued a scathing statement through his lawyers claiming he had offered at least three times to speak to US investigators and that they had used his status to gain publicity for their inquiry. The source claimed Palace staff were aposfuriousapos at Andrew, saying he propelled himself back into the public spotlight during the Duke of Edinburghaposs birthday week.

title: refugee week celebrate those who
story: NewsRefugee Week: We celebrate those who have gone above and beyond during the pandemicTo mark Refugee Week we celebrate the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees and asylum seekersShareCommentsByMaryam Qaiser:,  JUN NewsRefugee Week will celebrate the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees and asylum seekers " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMoving cities to start a new le can be a daunting experience for anyone but imagine being forced to flee your home because of a war. Many refugees and asylum seekers endure long, painful and desperate journeys - travelling by overcrowded boats, cramped lorries or on foot as they trek in search of safety. They don’t want to leave their home countries, their family and friends, but when war breaks out they are left with no other option. Tens of thousands of refugees have arrived in the UK in recent years and the majority have grabbed every opportunity they can to make a better le for themselves in their new homeland by studying, volunteering, working and starting their own businesses. Today marks the first day of Refugee Week  , celebrating the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees. This yearaposs theme is Imagine, and there will be an online programme of virtual workshops and activities. To mark Refugee Week, weaposve spoken to refugees and asylum seekers, many of whom have been volunteering tirelessly during the Covid- pandemic, about their new lives. Mahmoud Juma is a stall manager at Breadwinners Mahmoud came to England at the age of  without any family or friends. The journey from his home country Sudan took more than a year. Since then, he has been building his confidence and recently enrolled at college to study ESOL. He has also joined Breadwinners - a charity and social enterprise, which sees refugees and asylum seekers sell artisan bread on market stalls across London and has been delivering supplies during the Covid crisis. Mahmoud is now a stall manager for their Victoria Park branch. He is also supported by the Dost Centre, which works with newly-arrived young refugees and newly-arrived migrants.  Mahmoud, , says: “Before joining Breadwinners I didn’t have any confidence, I didn’t know any English, but since running the market I have met many dferent people from dferent cultures. It has helped my confidence and I really enjoy it. When I came to England I felt very lucky, because it was the safest place. It was a very, very painful and tough journey to get here. I faced a lot of challenges. When I first arrived I felt alone and I had no support until I came across some charities including Dost Centre. It was Marian from the Dost Centre who told me about the Breadwinners programme. It is great because I have been able to go camping, play football and make new friends thanks to the support from the centre. I feel this is the beginning of my future. During the Covid- crisis, I have delivered bread to  homes, through our new online orders. I have learnt a lot of skills from Breadwinners which will be valuable for my CV. I have a mentor with Breadwinners who has given me a lot of support, she has been texting me everyday to check I am okay during lockdown. In the future I would like to study and do a job in IT and technology.”  Since Breadwinners was set up in , they have helped  refugees and asylum seekers through their two programmes, Risers and Breadwinners. Risers supports young people who are seeking asylum by giving them work experience as market stall assistants. They also provide training and mentoring so they can build their skills and CV for future employment. The Breadwinners programme supports refugees with newly received status who are struggling to find work by providing opportunities for their first employment in the UK. They work as market stall managers, earning the UK Living Wage, until they are ready to find full time jobs or run their own business. Martin Campos, director at Breadwinners, says: The people we support have something very special, they have gone through so much and faced a lot of challenges, they will cherish every opportunity. It is crazy to see how the people we work with develop and how far they come, from when they first started with us. Some of the people we have supported have gone on to work in nursing, the tourism industry, sales and waitering. Zak Mohammed volunteers to deliver food parcels for Hope charity Zak, who is an asylum seeker, came to England in  from East Africa, but he has chosen not to share his past as he finds it too traumatic. Instead he has chosen to look at the positives in his le and is “thankful” for each day and is passionate about helping others. He is a volunteer with Hope - a Christian charity which works with local churches and community groups to support those in need. The Nottingham-based charity also helps to run food banks in the city. Since the start of the pandemic, Zak has delivered around  food parcels a week for the past two months to residents in need with charity volunteer and friend Julie James. He is also a volunteer with Derbyshire Refugee Solidarity and in the past, he has volunteered with a charity which supports children with disabilities called Umbrella and with Sue Ryder.  Zak, , says: “It feels good to help others, I enjoy volunteering. Everyone is dferent, some people like volunteering and doing something to keep busy, but it doesn’t always suit everyone. When I first came to this country I felt alone and I didn’t know anyone and I had nothing to do, which stressed me out. But now I volunteer with the Hope charity, I volunteer with the Derbyshire Refugee Solidarity and I am a keen runner so I have joined a running club in Derbyshire too. I have been delivering food parcels for Hope for about eight weeks now, it has helped me to continue learning English, I meet dferent people, and I have learnt more about Nottingham too. I don’t have any plans for the future, because I have learnt to take each day at a time and to just be happy.” Julie James, a former teacher of  years, now works in the charity sector focusing on refugees and asylum seekers. Julie, , from Nottingham, said: “Every refugee and asylum seeker who I have worked with has wanted to contribute to society in some way or another, or they’ve looked for paid employment and this needs to be celebrated. Through the charities I work with, refugees and asylum seekers have taken part in fundraising, volunteering and day trips out.”Mazin Saad volunteers to deliver food parcels and has been working at the Covid- testing centre Mazin, who is from Sudan, came to this country in  after a seven month journey. He has lived in Doncaster, South Yorkshire and most recently moved to London and was granted refugee status two years ago. Since the start of the Covid- pandemic, Mazin has been volunteering by delivering food parcels to refugees and asylum seekers in his local community. He also worked at a Covid- testing centre in March and he is now in the process of setting up a charity called Sudanese Solidarity Organisation, alongside his day job as a security officer. Mazin is also a member of the Good Chance Theatre where he regularly takes part in shows and workshops. He recently performed a poem about his journey to England for the theatre’s Migration Matters show.  Mazin, , says: Since the moment I was rescued as an asylum seeker by the Royal Navy, I have felt this country has given me so much that I want to give back. I have so many people to thank. During the pandemic I have been helping refugees and asylum seekers to make sure they have food and any support they need. I am looking to continue this work by setting up a charity called Sudanese Solidarity Organisation, we’re in the process of getting it set up and we have just done the logo. We want to eventually reach out to other countries and help as many people as possible. In this country the gap between refugees and asylum seekers is big, asylum seekers have very little money to live on, they need more support.  Over the years I have volunteered with the likes of British Red Cross and British Heart Foundation. It has helped with my confidence and it has allowed me to understand dferent cultures. I have met many dferent people through my volunteer work and have taken part in many social activities, especially with Good Chance Theatre. It has been great to engage in their workshops and help with fundraising too. Before the Covid- pandemic started, I was studying for a foundation course, which I am hoping to continue, which will hopefully allow me to enrol for an undergraduate course.Teem Khan, is an NHS worker, who also has his own fashion brand. He has been making masks. Teem, who is from East Africa, came to this country as a student in . He studied Travel and Tourism. After a y and challenging four year process, Teem went from being an asylum seeker to being granted refugee status  months ago. Teem, who lives in London, has recently started working for the NHS as a warehouse supervisor. Teem has recently started his own fashion brand, with the help of TERN - an organisation which helps refugees start a business. Teem has been making masks during the pandemic. Teem, , says: The process to become a refugee has ruined my mental health, it has been very traumatic, I was not able to work which was very hard for me. It still affects my anxiety today. However I had a lot of support from people, charities and organisations. I have recently started my own fashion brand, but I have had to put this on hold due to the panademic. I am now in week five of my new job. I have also been making masks in my own time. For every mask that I sell, I donate one to an asylum seeker. Asylum Seekers donapost have a lot of money to live on from the Government and buying a mask is probably the last thing on their mind. The masks are colourful, some have sequins, some are plain and some are made from denim, I have also used fabric with printed superheroes on including Toy Story.

title: schoolboy left huge gash head
story: NewsSchoolboy left with huge gash on head after ft tall white swan launches at himWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGE Jacob Gregory, , was hauled from the water with blood streaming from his head after the frightening attack by the huge birdShareCommentsByJim HardyTanveer MannDeputy News Editor:,  JUN NewsJacob Gregory was having a picnic when the attack happened " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn eight-year-old boy was left with a deep gash to his head after a ft tall white swan began attacking him. Jacob Gregory was having a picnic with his mum Sophie Hall, , and her partner Alex Conduit, , his daughter Bella, six, and their daughter Lily,  months, when the swan flew at him as he enjoyed a swim. The youngster was hauled from the water with blood streaming from his head after the attack by the huge bird which viciously pecked him. He was only saved when his brave mum ed fully-clothed into a river to rescue him. The Year  pupil at Bitham Brook Primary School in Westbury, Wilts, was taken to Frome Community Hospital with a deep wound in his head and is now recovering at home. Sophie Hall, of Oldfield Park, Westbury, said they chose a spot beside the River Wylye at picturesque Hanging Langford a few miles from their home. Jacob was playing in the river in his rubber ring along with a few other children in the water. Out of nowhere, a swan came charging towards him, and mounted him, flapping constantly, and attacked. Blood was pouring from his head. My partner and I ed into the water fully clothed to rescue my son and attempted to deter the swan from further attacking him. After dragging him from the water we were shocked to see he was covered in blood from a gash the swan had made on the back of his head. We took him to the minor injuries unit at Frome Community Hospital where he was treated and is now on medication for the wound. After the swan had been scared off by us, he then went up-stream and attacked another lady. My son was very shaken up but is very proud that he survived an animal attack and enjoys telling his story to people. At the hospital, nursing staff cleaned the wound but were reluctant to glue it closed because of fears that it might be contaminated with germs from the swan. Sophie said: They gave us a week’s supply of antibiotics and some special cream to put on it. The River Wylye between Hanging Langford and Steeple Langford is a popular picnic spot for families as there is parking opposite. Adults and children are able to swim and play in the river and afterwards sunbathe and dry off on the grassy river bank.

For more than  years the South Carolina store sold robes and hosted meetings for white supremacists - including supporters of the American Nazi party. It also sold Confederate memorabilia to sick collectors and was a hub for the KKK, which is responsible for more than  years of racist violence and killings. Now the new owner is fundraising to turn the building in Laurens into a community centre which celebrates ersity. Kindhearted Reverend David Kennedy brought a share in the shop from former Klansman Michael Burden Jr - and after a long legal battle ownership was finally passed to the  The New Beginning Missionary Baptist Church. In an astonishing act of forgiveness Rev Kennedy gave Burden a home, food for his family and a place to worship when he decided to put his former le behind him. Inthe ex-Ku Klux Klan member offered the minister the chance to buy a share of the Redneck Store, which finally closed in , having opened in . The story of Burdenaposs escape from the clutches of the white supremacist group is told in  movie Burden, starring Forrest Whitaker as Rev Kennedy.Back in , Burden said, the Washington Post reported : I want to apologize for causing an eyesore on Laurens.At one point, I believed in this. But it was the wrong belief.A fundraising page calling for the former shop to be turned into a beacon of hope says: Currently, the building sits dilapidated and abandoned, still containing remnants of its past tenant.There are Klan recruitment cards scattered around the main floor, Klan robe order forms still tacked up, and a floor-to-ceiling Swastika mural, left over from the - use of the property by members of the American Nazi Party. These visceral reminders of the building’s not-so-distant past only work to strengthen our resolve to finally create lasting change in Laurens, South Carolina. In place of the far-right meeting place, a new initiative called the Echo Project is being created instead.

Rayshard Brooks died in hospital on Friday night after a scuffle with officers outside a Wendyaposs in Georgia, having allegedly failed a sobriety test and resisting arrest after falling asleep in his car. The -year-old was a father to three girls and also had a stepson, WSB-TV reports. Investigators tonight released footage of the struggle with Atlanta Police that preceded him being shot and killed, which comes only weeks after the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis. It has sparked fresh demonstrations in the streets of Atlanta, which saw the Wendyaposs where Mr Brooks died lit on fire by protesters on Saturday night.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email  Images on local television showed the restaurant in flames while an anti-racist march has also completely shut down the Interstate  Highway. In a statement given to CNN, it says police were called to the restaurant at around .pm on Friday after a man was found to be asleep in his vehicle, blocking the drive-through lane and forcing other customers to drive around him. The GBI says police then gave Mr Brooks a sobriety test, which he failed, leading to the scuffle.  Attorneys L. Chris Stewart and Justin Miller, who are now representing Mr Brooksapos family, released the images on Saturday night. According to broadcaster CBS, he had spent the evening of his death celebrating his eldest daughteraposs birthday. The fatal shooting led to Atlantaaposs police chief, Erika Shields, resigning on Saturday. Shieldsapos statement said: For more than two decades, I have served alongside some of the finest women and men in the Atlanta Police Department. Out of a deep and abiding love for this City and this department, I offered to step aside as police chief. APD has my full support, and Mayor Bottoms has my support on the future direction of this department. I have faith in the Mayor, and it is time for the city to move forward and build trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. The Atlanta police involved in the shooting have been criticised for the use of firearms, given that Mr Brooks appears to have only had a Taser. The cityaposs mayor, Keisha Lance Bottoms, said: I do not believe that this was a justied use of deadly force and have called for the immediate termination of the officer. US politician Stacey Abrams, a former Georgia political candidate, is among those who have called for restrictions on police use of deadly force.Commenting on Twitter, she said: A Taser is not a deadly weapon. A gun is. Adrenaline and irritation are not the same as mortal fear. Running away should not be punishable by death. Public safety must mean the public is safe. All of us. title: dundee fc james mcpake championship return
story: Premiership managers are plotting their players’to training.But Dundee boss James McPake is still wondering when he’ll get the chance to lay out his Dark Blueprint.Amid continuing uncertainty over when the Championship will get started – and what form it will take – a provisional agreement has reportedly been reached between second-tier clubs to kick off a truncated -game season on October .The prospect of a -week wait until competitive football begins is far from ideal.But McPake reckons Championship clubs are becoming so desperate for a speck of light at the end of the tunnel that even an October start date will be gratefully received.He said: “I have heard bits and pieces but the problem, certainly for me, is that it is not definitive, it is a guide.“That’s why I am finding it tough and why every other manager, player and staff member in football is probably the same.“I am very cautious when I say how unsettling or how bad that is for us as there is a hell of a lot more going on in everyday le that means more than football.“Butthat dateis when we are starting then that will be a bonus for us. It will be a massive plus that we have something to work to.“Every manager will probably tell you the same – we need a date for when we are going to go back.“But as I said, I am cautious because there is an awful lot going on at the moment, from where you can take your kids to when you can go and meet other people.“Everything is changing and I don’t think football will be any dferent.”Reconstruction plans have now been run up the flagpole and ripped back down again more than once.Consensus, as is so often the case in Scottish football, has proved impossible to reach.Meanwhile clubs like Dundee, whose business model means they sit uncomfortably in the Championship, have been left in limbo.It has affected everyone at the club – and their manager is growing tired of the uncertainty.However, McPake is conscious of the wider issues in today’s world, and his annoyance is tempered by realism.He said: “There is frustration but for me that can’t be put on anyone.“There is a frustration in every industry about where we find ourselves.“We have never been in a situation like this before and what that brings is a real level of uncertainty.“We are looking for answers every day. I would be very reluctant to blame that on a single person or organisation as you can see it right across the world at the minute. But yes, it is frustrating.“If you are looking at it purely from a footballing point of view it is really dficult for the players, for the backroom staff and for the fans.“But again there is a bigger picture here in terms of a health crisis.“We have to be guided by the government and the governing bodies in football but it has not been easy.“Everybody is in the same boat really and there are no real answers to what is happening and when we can get back to what is perceived as normal.“It is dficult – there is no other way of putting it.”For as long as the Championship remains without a definitive restart date, many elements of Dundee’s normal business operations will remain on hold. On the football side, that means recruitment and day-to-day work with players.They are crucial to any club’s success.But McPake insists he – and everybody  at Dens Park who is not furloughed – is doing everything he can to ensure as seamless ato action as possible.“I speak to Johna couple of times a week or maybe more but nothing has really changed,” he said. “We are where we are and there is no definitive date to when we can start back. It is not like a normal summer or break in the season like a winter one or international break.“There is always a structure to football and when you are back. The players, staff, everybody knows that but at the moment that has completely gone.“It is everyone’s longest lay-off – we are now getting to the stage where the players have been off the same amount of timethey had a serious injury so that brings its problems physically and mentally.“It is just about trying to get everything right so that when we do get the green light to start back we are in as good a position as possible.”EXCLUSIVE: Ex-Dundee striker Peter MacDonald confirms he’s hanging up his boots and says best day of his career came as a Dark Blues player" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fc-peter-macdonald-retirement-st-johnstone-rangers embed # secretWJcMNsFIpT" data-secret"WJcMNsFIpT" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
