title: scotland-gets-set-welcome-tourists
story: The Scottish Government has given the tourism and hospitality sectors a provisional reopening date of July , assuming the fight to suppress Covid- continues to be successful.But amid warnings the two-metre social-distancing rule will lead to pubs, restaurants and museums being restricted in their ability to claw back much-needed cash, Highlands and Islands businesses have stated that ferry restrictions are ldquosimply catastrophic for trade.The North Coast  route, which provides up to pound million to the Highlands economy a year, is expecting even more Scots to enjoy its sites and spend money in local businesses this summer.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of NC, said: ldquoWith international tourism shredded and the thoughts of many turning to post-lockdown travel, there is every likelihood more Scots than ever before may well follow the lead of tens of thousands of visitors who have already explored the -mile route.:Coronavirus: Edinburgh family fear they brought Covid to Scotland after sons symptoms dismissed as just a cold after Italian ski tripldquoSeismic change in how Scots and other UK nations holiday as a result of Covid- could result in a staycation boom, helping to ensure the success of the NC, businesses and communities along the route continues through dficult times.ldquoWersquore expecting to see more UK visitors heading to Scotland and driving and cycling will be the way people will want to take their holidays.With more people expected to travel by car this summer amid social distancing and capacity concerns around public transport, car parks and public toilets are set to be reopened ndash with hand hygiene playing a leading role in the continued fight against coronavirus.Forestry and Land Scotland operates dozens of visitor centres and car parks across the Highlands.Chief executive Simon Hodgson, said: ldquoWe are grateful that many people have exercised their patience throughout lockdown and we will be looking to carry out the necessary maintenance and safety checks on our car parks and other leisure and recreation facilities that will allow us to gradually reopen them.ldquoWe anticipate that we will have some car parks and mountain bike trails open by the end of phase two and will be working towards opening our visitor centres as soon as it is practicable and safe to do so in phase three.A spokesperson for Highland Council said the authority is working towards reopening as many toilets and car parks as possible.But the anticipated staycation boom is unlikely to be felt in Scotlandrsquos island communities after CalMac Ferries warned that with current social-distancing measures continuing, only % of normal passenger numbers will be able to travel.Rob McKinnon, chief executive of Outer Hebrides Tourism, said: ldquoMany tourism businesses on the islands which have seen no revenue since October  are on a knersquos edge and will be unable to survive until April  without some trading season this year, or further Government support, which has not yet been proposed.:Scotland set to enter lockdown Phase  NEXT WEEK - what changes for youldquoWersquod welcome a boost or a bounce, as opposed to a surge or an invasion, in autumn, when people who have been unable to come earlier in the year decide to visit in October or November which would really help our businesses, when social distance happens naturally, and you do have the space to feed your soul. Wersquoll need a bit of patience and understanding as we get back into gear and adjust to social distancing, restock some supplies, and deal with everyonersquos nervousness as we adapt to the new normal.ldquoWe are lucky that many of our visitors are regulars and we can rely on them to do their part.Gordon Morrison, chief executive ofthe Association of Scottish Visitor Attractions, has indicated that many outdoor attractions could reopen as soon as next weekend,Nicola Sturgeon confirms stage two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos roadmap to easing the lockdown later this week ndash but warned that ldquomany are weighing up whether it will be viable to open on July .He added: ldquoRegardless of when attractions choose to reopen, there will be a signicantly reduced number of visitors to our sites this year and there is absolutely no doubt that a longer-term support package for the sector will definitely be needed to ensure the survival of many of our members.Pubs and restaurants are eager to welcome customers again, with those with outdoor spaces set to be able to reopen in phase two of the exit strategy.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the Scottish Beer  Pub Association, said: ldquoIt is important consumers feel safe and comfortable when they are finally allowed to enjoy a beer in a pub again, with operators across Scotland busy over the coming weeks getting their premises ready for opening in the new normal.ldquoThere are still issues needing addressed ahead of reopening for the pub sector though, with the majority of premises unable to viably operate at a two-metre social distance.

title: sir-tom-devine-scotlands-role-slavery-must-acknowledged
story: Devine says that attacking statues of public figures connected to the th and th-century slave trade ldquoachieves little and fails to acknowledge the real truth of historic Scottish involvement in the slave systems.ldquoTargeting statues is a largely meaningless gesture which might make some people feel good about themselves for a little while, he says. ldquoThis though, does little to address the very real and ongoing issue of racial prejudice in Scotland and throughout the UK.Devine spoke out at the end of a week in which attention in Scotland has been focused on the imposing statue of Henry Dundas in Edinburghrsquos St Andrew Square which dominates the city centre.Dundas, one of the most powerful figures in Scotland in the early-th century, used his influence to delay the abolition of the Atlantic slave trade by  years. Edinburgh City Council is to consider a plan to rededicate the statue to those who continued to suffer enslavement during this period.Across the world other statues have been targeted in the wake of international protests about the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis two weeks ago. In Bristol last Sunday, a statue of the th-century slave trader, Edward Colston, was felled by protesters and flung into the harbour.Devine insisted that focusing merely on statues and other artefacts from the past was misplaced. ldquoIf people want to talk about Scottish involvement in slavery they need to be aware of the full picture. In the th and early-th centuries the Scottish nation as a whole was lsquocomplicitrsquo in slavery. The markets and financial s from lsquothe nefarious businessrsquo helped to lay the foundation for modern Scotland and shaped the economy from which we now benefit.In , Devine edited a collection of essays about Scotlandrsquos historic involvement in the slave plantations. Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past demonstrated how all levels of Scottish society, from the early-th century to the end of slavery in the British Empire, were directly or indirectly affected.:Without slavery Glasgow wouldnt exist: The brutal truth about Scotlands slaving pastldquoThe new research showed that merely concentrating on prominent mercantile figures fails to take account of the fact that Scottish society as a whole benefited from chattel slavery: weavers of lsquoslave clothrsquo for the West Indies fishermen who exported dried fish to feed the slaves workers in the mills who processed the raw cotton harvested by slave labour the crews of the vessels who sailed across the Atlantic and the officials, lawyers and clergymen who administered the slave colonies and the spiritual needs of their owners.ldquoOnly by acknowledging the full extent of this nationrsquos role in slavery can we begin to construct a meaningful programme of response today to that dark period of history.lsquorsquoI am convinced that the evidence we now have suggests Scottish modernisation was even more dependent on the slavery factor than England. This was not because of involvement in the slave trade itself. Ships from Scottish ports rarely took part in that horrible commerce in human beings after . Rather it was based on the overwhelming place of tobacco, sugar and then cotton in Scottish external trade. The remarkable boom in these commodities depended entirely on armies of black slave labourers.In , Glasgow University published a report, based on more than two years of research, that revealed it benefited directly from the slave trade in Africa and the Caribbean in the th and th centuries. Its audit put the figure at pound million in todayrsquos money. Following this the university launched a wide-ranging ldquoreparative justice programme to include the creation of a centre for the study of slavery and to establish ties with the University of the West Indies.The study also raised questions about how the wealth of Glasgow and other parts of Scotland was accumulated. Devine praised the universityrsquos research and openness. ldquoThe research confirms that manmore Scots gained from the colonial trades based on slave labour than the tobacco lords and sugar princes who are now attracting such virulent media and political condemnation, he said.:Hundreds turn out lsquoto protectrsquo Glasgow war memorialldquoTherefore, it follows that today there must be institutions and families with links to those times and who prospered from the profits of chattel slavery. But so far, in Scotland, only the University of Glasgow has admitted how it benefited and how it intends to proceed by way of some form of recompense to the people of the West Indies. Why are others silent ldquoOne positive consequence of the current furore has been the triggering of a deeper awareness of the inequalities that black people in Britain and the US continue to encounter to this day and which have undeniable connections to slavery. ldquoYet in order to begin to heal that wound in Scotland, a soundly-based and open knowledge of the nationrsquos central part in slave history is an essential precondition.

title: shops-call-re-opening-date-announced
story: The Scottish Retail Consortium wants a provisional reopening date so shops can prepare to open their doors to customers again.Non-essential shops have been shut since lockdown began on March  and many are facing a battle to survive the longer their doors remain closed.In England, clothes stores and bookshops are starting to open again from tomorrow but there is no date yet when this might happen in Scotland.Ewan MacDonald-Russell of the Scottish Retail Consortium said: ldquoWe really need an indicative timetable so we can put the right measures in place so wersquore ready to trade and customers can have a bit of confidence when they can come back to shops and get the products wersquore all hoping theyrsquoll want to buy.The Scottish Government has produced a route map out of lockdown with dferent measures occurring at dferent stages but no dates are attached to the phases.A spokesman said: ldquoWe have a review point on Thursday at which time we will consider further, safe progression through the route map.ldquoOur total package for businesses during this unprecedented economic crisis now exceeds pound. billion. This support, which is under constant review, includes almost poundm of non-domestic rates relief and a pound.bn business grants scheme.ldquoImportantly, we have extended the eligibility criteria for our small business and retail, hospitality and leisure grants, and we have extended the upper threshold for retail, hospitality or leisure properties with inidual rateable values of up to pound, each. We have also published workplace guidance to support the retail sectorrsquosto trading.The national clinical director, Professor Jason Leitch, told BBC Scotland he was hopeful there could be good news for retailers soon. He said: ldquoShops will be part of our conversation this week as we move towards hopefully phase two of the route map on Thursday and Friday and conversations around next weekend.Retailers say they need a provisional date to help prepare shops for social distancing measures, bringing back staff and planning sales promotions.They also fear that the longer they are closed, the more people will shop on the internet, and perhaps continue to do so in the long term.Meanwhile, the Higher Education Minister has warned that Scottish universities could suffer long-term damage caused by the Covid- outbreak as well as losing access to European funds as Britain leaves the EU.The Scottish Funding Councilrsquos recent analysis suggests the countryrsquos universities will lose around poundm this year and between poundm and poundm next year Richad has written to the UK Science Minister Amanda Solloway: ldquoItrsquos vital both for Scotlandrsquos economic recovery and to protect the nationrsquos global reputation for science and research excellence that the UK Treasury signals substantial support for our universities in the coming days.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  One Glasgow boy ran to tell the farmer    39 they coos are eating a    your grass  39
story: With falling temperatures, the village moved back indoors. Yoursquod scarcely know that there has been any lting of lockdown. One neighbour says her grandmother scoffs at the idea that the coronavirus crisis is like the last war, when she was a child in a nearby town. Although they were often hungry, they had complete freedom. Even when the air raid siren went, and they had to e into shelters, they did not feel the all-pervasive threat of today.Nor, unless they were extremely remote or unlucky, were people shut off from each other. We talk a lot about the power of modern technology to keep us connected, but in those times, whether you were in a village or a city, there was daily contact with other folk, evenyou lived alone. People wouldnrsquot have felt the need for video calls when they could nip out of theirdoor and visit whoever they liked nearby. The Blitz spirit is not entirely a myth, but the circumstances in which it thrived were very dferent from this pandemic.My mother lived in London and, in , like countless city children, was evacuated to the country. She was luckier than many, being sent not to strangers but to an aunt, who lived in Herefordshire, near the Welsh border. There was no running water, light was by paraffin lamp, her uncle was an irascible war veteran, and her aunt would often retreat to bed for days, finding the extra responsibility rather too much. But for an -year-old, collecting eggs from under hens, sauntering up the lane for still-warm jugs of milk from the farm, and seeing a night-time sky lit by stars was a revelation. From then on, she counted the days until she could leave London forever.Not all evacuees felt the same way. Encountering beetles and bugs for the first time was hard enough, but herds of cows with a bull among them must have been pretty alarming. One boy, who had never previously left the Gallowgate, ran to tell the farmer that ldquothey coos are eating arsquo your grass. Another Glaswegian, taken into a Perthshire home, escaped onto the roof when they ran him a bath. He thought they were trying to drown him.Recalling that period, my mother spoke of country folksrsquo shock at the poverty of inner city children, who had come from slums. Those who organised the mass evacuation were appalled to discover that, when asked to provide each child with a change of clothing, a toothbrush and enough food for a dayrsquos journey, a lot of families were unable to do so. It was a sobering eye-opener. Rural hardship was re, but it did not compare to the scale of urban deprivation: barefoot youngsters with rickets, scurvy, ringworm, or so underfed they were the colour of lard.Itrsquos hard to imagine what it must have felt like to be dropped into a world of fields and trees and pitch black nights, when you were used to well-lit canyons of concrete and stone or to find yourself alone in a bed, when usually therersquod be siblings on all sides, keeping you warm, and your parents only a step away. Some children were so miserable, they had to be sent home. For others, like my mother, it sparked a lelong love of the countryside.Not that she idealised her auntrsquos way of le. Some aspects of it were, for a Londoner, like stepping back in time. Nor, in the s, was there any glamorising of country le. It was often equated with backward attitudes and ignorance. If anything, most villagers dreamed of escaping to the city, or at least the suburbs, and a clean, warm house with all mod-cons.Irsquove been reading Dirk Bogardersquos memoir, Great Meadow, in which he recalls his childhood in the Sussex Downs, from the age of six. Between  and , he spent weekends and long spells of holiday in what his affluent parents called a cottage, but photos show as a substantial house. Later he was packed off to Glasgow, which he loathed, but thatrsquos another story. In Great Meadow, he and his little sister were looked after by a nanny, while his actress mother swanned around in a kimono, and his father raced up and down to London where he was on The Timesrsquos picture desk. Bogarde often mentions the healthiness of the country, compared to London, where public transport was frowned on, because of the risk of germs. This was a legacy, perhaps, of the Spanish flu.Bogarde loved everything about the cottage, but the most noteworthy feature was the outside lavatory. Every Friday he had to dig a hole in the garden and, under cover of dusk, empty the privy bucket into it. His great fear was of tripping, because sanitation was basic. Theyrsquod have a weekly bath, filled by their nanny, but his parents preferred going to the nearest pub for their ablutions.Years ago I visited friends in rural Perthshire who had an outside toilet. I rather liked it: it was made of wood, and smelled of sawdust. Unlike the shed at the bottom of many cottage gardens, one wall was open, so the view was lovely, even in the snow. You didnrsquot have to crunch over snails in the dark to reach it ndash bedrooms came with chamberpots ndash and as a guest there was no fear of ever being asked to empty it. To watch him on screen, yoursquod never think Bogarde was the man to cope with such a noisome task. If for any reason it suddenly becomes a necessary chore in our cottage, Irsquoll be with the Gallowgate evacuees, heading straight back to the flushing loos of the Merchant City.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter   Bagpuss Boris  followed the wrong science
story: The PM is losing supporters left and right. The Government is rudderless, drting making contradictory decisions or no decisions at all.Boris Johnson had nothing sensible to say about the Black Lives Matter demos which drove a coach and horses through the lockdown. He could either have endorsed the protests as legitimate on moral grounds, or called on the police to enforce the law. He did neither until forced to. Leadership was lacking.The belated introduction of a -day quarantine for travellers to Britain seems like a self-destructive exercise in closing the door after the viral horse has bolted. His Government is cancelling border checks on the , lorries that enter the UK every day, while also saying that the Brexit transition period will not be extended.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson putting political interests ahead of the public interestJohnson is accused of allowing children in England to go to theme parks but not to schools, leading to further problems for students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The two-metre rule is causing massive problems as the economy tanks, yet the medical evidence for its effectiveness is contradictory.But the most serious accusation made last week against Boris Johnson was that he was asleep at the wheel in early March, and that his dilatory behaviour led to the deaths of tens of thousands of people.The claim was made by the former SAGE member, Professor Neil Ferguson .ldquoHad we introduced lockdown a week earlier, the Imperial College epidemiologist told MPs last week, ldquowersquod have reduced the final death toll by at least half.In other words,the UK Government had closed the schools and shops on March  instead of March , the official death toll might have been , instead of ,. This retrospectively validates Fergusonrsquos own forecast back in March that, on his model, lockdown should have kept the death toll to around ,.I think most now accept that the UK did just about everything wrong in its response to Covid-. We didnrsquot close the borders, didnrsquot protect care homes, abandoned testing and locked down too late. The question is: who is to blame for all this The editor of The Lancet, Richard Horton, in ldquoThe Covid Catastrophe which is to be published this week, names the guilty man: Boris Johnson. He failed to attend crucial meetings of COBRA, the Cabinet crisis committee, failed to listen to scientists, and thought the country should ldquotake it on the chin in order to protect the economy.But it was not just the PM who delayed lockdown by one week. This was also the policy of the Scottish Government.I happened to be in the Scottish parliament on March , the day that Leo Varadkar announced the closure of schools and universities in Ireland. At First Ministerrsquos Questions, Nicola Sturgeon explained why she was not following suit. She was, she insisted, ldquofollowing the science.School children sent home were likely to take the disease into their communities and to older people, ldquowhich might be a greater risk in terms of spread of infection than their being in school. She also said that parents would have to stay at home to look after them and this would denude staff for essential services like the NHS.:London Protests: More than  arrested as Boris Johnson condemns far-right protests as lsquoracist thuggeryrsquoIt all seemed sensible at the time. The national clinical director, Jason Leitch, was all over the media saying that the vast majority of us were going to get the virus anyway, because there was no vaccine, and that we had to ldquoprotect the vulnerable as it ldquoworked its way through the population.The release of SAGE minutes two weeks ago confirms that the scientic advisers were at best cool about lockdown. They may not have been in thrall to heartless herd immunity, but they did believe that trying to suppress the virus would be counterproductive.On March , the minutes say "SAGE was unanimous that measures seeking to completely suppress the spread of Covid- will cause a second peak.It added that it was ldquoa near certainty that countries such as China, where heavy suppression is under way, will experience a second peak once measures are relaxed.The scientic consensus was that eradication of the disease was not possible because it would spread until herd immunity ndash % of the population ndash finally burned the virus out. But Jacinda Ardern, the prime minister of New Zealand, took a dferent view. She closed the borders immediately cases appeared and kept them closed, and imposed a severe lockdown internally and suppressed the virus until it disappeared. Last week she declared victory over Covid ."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","description": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media gHqFBAP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests gHqFBAP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Only time will tell whether SAGE was right. There may indeed be a second wave and New Zealand will have very little immunity to it. Borders cannot be kept closed forever. However, the minutes seem to confirm that, as Professor Lawrence Freedman argued in the New Statesman, ldquothe Government was largely following SAGErsquos advice.Some have claimed that Nicola Sturgeon wanted to follow dferent advice and was overruled by Westminster. That isnrsquot the case. The First Minister was following the same scientic advice as Westminster, and made clear she did not believe lockdown was yet necessary or desirable on March .Itrsquos hard to believe that a weekrsquos delay could have led to , deaths, as many as on the first day of the Battle of the Somme. Scientists will debate this for years.Indeed, analysts in Bristol, led by the mathematical modeller Professor Simon Wood, now claim now that the disease peaked before lockdown was introduced, suggesting that SAGE was right.SAGE had always argued, as the minutes show, that the best way to contain the spread was hand washing, social distancing, and protecting the old and vulnerable. The UK Government was only persuaded of lockdown by Neil Fergusonrsquos infamous forecast, on March , that without it , would die.The one thing we have learned from coronavirus is that science is not a monolith and that scientists disagree as much as politicians. All of which makes little dference to the state of the PMrsquos popularity, which dropped dramatically during Cummingsgate and has not recovered.Tory commentators are whispering that Johnson has lost it, doesnrsquot look well. Has he fully recovered from Covid- himself  He nearly died, after all.Itrsquos dficult to tell with Boris Johnson because he never seems particularly in command. For an intelligent man, he is remarkably inarticulate. He ldquoums and ldquoahs his way through Prime Ministerrsquos Questions ashe is making it up as he goes along. The suspicion is that he is, and that he relied too much on Dominic Cummings to do the thinking for him.Before he became Prime Minister, Johnson had a reputation for being lazy and shallow. Three years ago, his Tory colleague and rival Michael Gove said that ldquoBoris cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead. Gove recanted ndash but it could be he was right all along.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

However, the minutes seem to confirm that, as Professor Lawrence Freedman argued in the New Statesman, ldquothe Government was largely following SAGErsquos advice.Some have claimed that Nicola Sturgeon wanted to follow dferent advice and was overruled by Westminster. That isnrsquot the case. The First Minister was following the same scientic advice as Westminster, and made clear she did not believe lockdown was yet necessary or desirable on March .Itrsquos hard to believe that a weekrsquos delay could have led to , deaths, as many as on the first day of the Battle of the Somme. Scientists will debate this for years.Indeed, analysts in Bristol, led by the mathematical modeller Professor Simon Wood, now claim now that the disease peaked before lockdown was introduced, suggesting that SAGE was right.SAGE had always argued, as the minutes show, that the best way to contain the spread was hand washing, social distancing, and protecting the old and vulnerable. The UK Government was only persuaded of lockdown by Neil Fergusonrsquos infamous forecast, on March , that without it , would die.The one thing we have learned from coronavirus is that science is not a monolith and that scientists disagree as much as politicians. All of which makes little dference to the state of the PMrsquos popularity, which dropped dramatically during Cummingsgate and has not recovered.Tory commentators are whispering that Johnson has lost it, doesnrsquot look well. Has he fully recovered from Covid- himself  He nearly died, after all.Itrsquos dficult to tell with Boris Johnson because he never seems particularly in command. For an intelligent man, he is remarkably inarticulate. He ldquoums and ldquoahs his way through Prime Ministerrsquos Questions ashe is making it up as he goes along. The suspicion is that he is, and that he relied too much on Dominic Cummings to do the thinking for him.Before he became Prime Minister, Johnson had a reputation for being lazy and shallow. Three years ago, his Tory colleague and rival Michael Gove said that ldquoBoris cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead. Gove recanted ndash but it could be he was right all along.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: scotlands-schools-unlikely-return-normal-next-summer
story: John Swinney said next years exams ndash which would normally start in late April ndash could also be pushed back due to the impact of coronavirus.He said there is a "working assumption" that exams will take place in , but schools are also being asked to prepare for their cancellation.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she wanted schools toto normal as soon as possible.Schools have been shut since March, leaving the vast majority of pupils to finish the academic year from home. Exams were also cancelled for the first time ever.The Scottish Government has announced plans to reopen schools on August  with a "blended" learning model, which will see pupils spend up to half of their time learning from home.Union leaders have warned this model could last the entire school year.Mr Swinney said it will be a legal requirement for parents to send their children to school, regardless of anxiety about the virus, but the homeschooling portion of the curriculum will not be legally enforced.He told the BBCs Sunday Politics Scotland: "I dont want it to go on for a minute longer than its necessary, because I accept that the blended learning model is not as good a model as the one that we had before coronavirus had the effect that it had, resulting in lockdown."But he said it was "unlikely" things wouldto normal before the end of the school year, adding: "Well have to maintain the social distancing approaches for some considerable time to come."There will be changes and dferences in the way we deliver education as a consequence of the requirements of physical distancing."There will be, on an ongoing basis, factors that we have to bear in mind in how schools operate but, obviously, the more we can try to expand the capacity and the involvement of young people in their education in face-to-face schooling, well be taking those opportunities when it is safe to do so."Mr Swinney said it is possible exams could start later in the year to give pupils more learning time.However they would need to take place early enough to fit in with university and college timetables.Ms Sturgeon was later asked about the issue during her daily coronavirus update.The First Minister said: "We continue to be cautious in our assessments, because to do anything other than that risks giving people a misleading picture of what the future might look like."She added: "We are being cautious now about theof time that some kind of blended model may be required for."But on the other hand, we shouldnt get to a point where we are accepting now that for a certain period of time schooling will not be normal."I want to get young people not just back to school, but back to normal schooling as quickly as it is deemed safe to do that, so we will be working hard to do that."And I hope it is the case that over the next academic year we do see schools ing to normal, but it is not possible right now for us, at this vantage point, to give dates and say that with certainty."Askedparents should prepare for part-time home learning to continue until potentially next summer, Ms Sturgeon said ministers are trying to be as open with people as they can.She said: "Part of that involves just being open about the uncertainties."What John [Swinney] was doing earlier on is what Ive done today, which is to say we have to be frank with people that we dont yet have complete certainty over what the next few months will look like, so we cant rule out some continued change to the model of education that young people will be following, at this stage, over the course of the next academic year."Ms Sturgeon said ministers want schools toto normal as quickly as possible.She added: "These are all really dficult issues to be absolutely certain about right now, which is why sometimes, I suppose, we err on the side of the worst case scenario."Were doing everything we can right now to avoid having a second wave of this virus come the autumn [and] winter, but none of us can rule that out right now."The First Minister signalled more money could be made available to councils to help schools cope with social distancing measures.She said: "Local authorities are making plans and putting plans in place for the blended model of learning we will see from August  onwards."The Scottish Government will then look at that and we will make judgments around what additional support is going to be necessary."Earlier, Mr Swinney said he was supportive of local authorities seeking to use public buildings to hold classes, such as town halls and libraries, as well as hiring more teachers to increase the number of classes and reduce the size of the cohorts, and was willing to enter talks with councils on funding needs.He said: "What Ive said to local authorities is come forward with those proposals and well look at those proposals."Councils are beginning to set out the approaches that theyre taking, they will be considered and assessed by Her Majestys Inspectorate of Education and will be tested to see whether or not these ideas can be utilised."A total of , patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from , on Saturday.Statistics show that , people have tested positive for the virus, up by  from , the previous day.There are  people in hospital with confirmed or suspected Covid-, a decrease of  in  hours.Of these patients,  were in intensive care, down by five from the previous day.

title: issue-day-anna-wintours-in-vogue-apology
story: American Vogue Famed for her unorm bob and supersize sunglasses, London-born Wintour, now , has helmed US Vogue since , having edited British Vogue briefly beforehand, during a period that became known by staff as "the Wintour of Our Discontent as she made the publication her own.Ice Queen Amid reports of intimidating, brusque behaviour, the most powerful style maker in the world was nicknamed ldquoNuclear Wintour at the magazine. Asked about the monicker on US TV in , she said: ldquoIf Im such a bitch then they must really be a glutton for punishment, because theyre still here. If one comes across as sometimes being cold or brusque, its simply because Im striving for the best."But a new memoir has added fuel to the fire Or ice to the glacier. Wintourrsquos former colleague, Andreacute Leon Talley, who was editor-at-large for Vogue for decades, claims in his upcoming memoir, ldquoThe Chfon Trenches, that Wintour is simply ldquonot capable of ldquohuman kindness, claiming she prefersto mingle with A-listers such as George Clooney and Roger Federer. Talley writes: ldquoShe is immune to anyone other than the powerful and famous people who populate the pages of Vogue.He was the first black man to take on his role Talley said that ldquoAt one point, I was the onlyblack person on Annarsquos staff, but he was then frozen out, saying: ldquoI had suddenly become too old, too overweight, too uncool, I imagined, for Anna Wintour.Silver screen In , US writer Lauren Weisberger published her debut novel, "The Devil Wears Prada, inspired by her time as a put-upon assistant to Wintour at Vogue. Speculation was re that the magazine editor in the book, Miranda Priestly, was based on Wintour and in the movie version released in , Meryl Streep played the ice queen editor.No love on the elevator Her biographer, Jerry Oppenheimer, wrote that Wintour dictates everything that goes into the magazine, "along with the behaviour and attitude in its hallowed halls, from how subordinates should act on the elevators when shes aboard - subdued, respectful, no eye contact - to how they are supposed to dressthey want to work there...thus naked legs and open-toed stilettos in the bitter New York winter were requirements of the famed and feared editrixrsquos unwritten dress code."Apology Amid the winds of change blowing across the world, Wintour sent an internal email to her staff last week that has since been leaked. In it, she writes: ldquoI want to say plainly that I know Vogue has not found enough ways to elevate and give space to Black editors, writers, photographers, designers and other creators. We have made mistakes too, publishing images or stories that have been hurtful or intolerant. I take full responsibility for those mistakes.She has pledged change Wintour wrote: ldquoIt canrsquot be easy to be a black employee at Vogue, and there are too few of you. I know that it is not enough to say we will do better, but we will mdash and please know that I value your voices and responses as we move forward.

title: scotrail-unveils-design-active-travel-carriages-boost-scotlands-cyclists
story: Cyclists and those carrying large sporting equipment will now have designated space on some ScotRail services which will take them to some of the countrys most popular beauty spots.An eye-catching design is boasted along the side of the carriage, depicting typical Highland sceneryalong with some of the best-known visible landmarks along the West Highland Line, including the Glenfinnan monument and viaduct, Skye Cuillin mountain range, Ben Lomond, and the castle on Loch Awe.:Face coverings now lsquoexpectedrsquo on all public transportIt was designed by Scottish artist Peter McDermott, who says it was a great pleasure to be asked to be involved.Five Class  trains will be able to carry up to  bikes on the West Highland Line, with custom designed racks for bikes and large items of luggage as well as more seats for customers.The trains will also support winter sports in Scotland during the winter months, accommodating large bulky items such as ski bags and rucksacks.They will also undergoa full interior and exterior refresh including installation of free WiFi, at seat power sockets and a refurbished toilet with controlled emission toilettank.The first carriage is due to be complete later this year, and will enter service one staff can be safely trained.Tom Smith, ScotRail Project Manager, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be able to share the exterior design of our first active travel carriage.ldquoPeter McDermottrsquos eye-catching design pays real homage to the beautul and tranquil West Highland Line.:Unionrsquos health and safety fears over ticket office plans at Queen Street in the wake of coronavirus pandemicldquoWersquore living in uncertain times, but when these carriages are eventually introduced, it will be a welcome boost for cyclists and those in search of outdoor pursuits along Scotlandrsquos most scenic railways.Bill Reeve, Transport Scotlandrsquos Director of Rail, said: ldquoIt is exciting to see the finalised design for these Class  carriages, one which incorporates the beauty of the Scottish landscape whilst clearly promoting their active travel purpose. This comes as a result of close collaboration between the artist Peter McDermott and ScotRail.ldquoWe look forward to seeing what are sure to become iconic carriages enter passenger service in the future, once we have reached more certain times in our current phased exit from COVID- lockdown.

title: laughter-big-yins-best-medicine
story: Now Sir Billy Connolly has told how he has used comedy to stay positive and cope with thoughts of dying.The comedy legend, now , was diagnosed with Parkinsonrsquos disease in . And he said that while some people turn to religion or other ldquotricks to deal with the inevitable, comedy was his release from ldquothe terror of death.The Glasgow-born star, speaking in the final part of his BBC Scotland documentary Billy and Us, which airs on Thursday, has told how, as his condition worsens, he relies more on laughterto get through the grimmest moments.He says: ldquoThe best way to deal with the dark side of le is to laugh right in its face. Death  Everybody knows itrsquos coming and people try all sorts of tricks, religion etcetera, to deal with it, but comedy can release you from your terror of death -- you can treat it lightly.:Billy Connolly: Why Ill never apologise over religion routine that caused uproarldquoItrsquos like the big bully at school, you can say lsquoI could beat him any dayrsquo, as long as hersquos not there. You can kid that way and comedy will allow you to do that.Connolly has previously discussed his struggle with Parkinsonrsquos and last year told how he could feel himself ldquoslipping away. The disease also had an impact on his stage performances.Speaking in Billy and Us, he reveals how he refuses to accept pessimistic attitudes and uses laughter to attack his condition ldquohead on.He said: ldquoNow that Irsquom getting older and sicker, itrsquos important that my comedy kicks in.ldquoI went to a doctor in New York and he was a Russian, and he said lsquoYou realise itrsquos an incurable disease rsquo and I said lsquoOh come on, behave yourself. Instead of saying itrsquos incurable, say we have yet to find a cure. It gives me a wee light at the end of the tunnel.ldquoI was telling some people Irsquove started to drool, which is a new one on me. I never knew how to deal with it, so Irsquove come to the conclusion that women find drooling attractive and therersquos a woman who has a new record out that only I have heard lsquoI love a man with a shiny chinrsquo.He even poked fun at his own illness at the end of his most recent run of stand up performances by playing out with a s rock n roll classic.He added: ldquoI ended my shows with lsquoWhole Lotta Shakinrsquo Goinrsquo onrsquo. Yoursquove got to attack it head on. As far as Irsquom concerned, shaking is the new cool.The programme also features highlights from Connollyrsquos ground-breaking routines about death, illness and even incontinence, which he said had the power to make the world a better place.He said: ldquoIrsquove done a lot of stuff like that, where Irsquove got rid of my own taboos by making fun of them and shining a light on them, and itrsquos worked out rather well.:Billy Connolly on pathetic Scottish Labour and what he really thinks about independenceldquoThe comedian is doing it for laughs. Hersquos not doing it like a social worker to make the world better, but accidentally he can do that - he can make the world a better place. Poets and comedians, they are in charge of making the world a better place - leaving it a better place than they found it.ldquoThe incontinence trousers was one of the most successful things I ever did. I couldnrsquot believe the result that it had and has to this day. I would make fun of darkness, and itrsquos a joy to do. Humour will always be in a state of change, and dferent moral realms will come and go and the humour will adjust itself to suit.ldquoJust now I think itrsquos a bit up itself. Itrsquos such a tender thing, comedy. When itrsquos picked up the wrong way it can fall terribly the wrong way, but when picked up the right way it can really enlighten people and make a situation that was awful, better.ldquoI used to talk about my fatherrsquos stroke. The other men in the hospital, guys who were seriously ill, I would make fun of it. Itrsquos just a way of dealing with it yourself I think. Comedy is great that way.

title: scotlands-urban-buy-out-blueprint-towns
story: Partly paid for by the people of the town, with the red stone steeple a stonersquos throw away and the statue of Robert Burns at the head of the street, the ornate fountainrsquos unveiling in  drew crowds to the bustling town centre in their droves.As years passed, just like many Scottish towns, the family-run shops, hotels and cafes changed hands. Big name retailers moved in and, as time wore on, the ldquoto let signs began to appear.Now, however, that same community spirit that raised pound.s d from local people to pay for their th century fountain is helping to revive Dumfries High Street, in a project that, it is hoped, will provide inspiration forother towns up and down the country.Rather than wait for someone  to step in to breathe new le into the empty shops and buildings, local people are pushing ahead with plans to take back control of their neglected high street.Work is expected to start within weeks on the first High Street building to be reclaimed from lying empty.While its Victorian frontage with all its unique character will remain in place, a pound. million redevelopment will see the former Bakerrsquos Oven shop reborn as seven new affordable rent flats, with space for start-up businesses, art exhibitions and socialand community enterprise projects.Named ldquoThe Oven, it is one of eight retail units included in community-run Midsteeple Quarterrsquos innovative plans to rejuvenate the heart of the town as a place to live, visit, shop, dine and be entertained.The innovative project is being eyed up by towns and organisations across theUK, anxious to seeits community buy-out model might be a viable option to help transform other places hit by a sht towards internet shopping and out of town retail parks.ldquoFor a long time the town centre was bookies, charity shops and empty units. Dumfries has just said lsquoenough is enoughrsquo, says Evie Copland, chairwoman of the community benefit society, Dumfries High Street Ltd, which is behind the Midsteeple Quarter project.ldquoPeople had been buying buildings in the High Street for too long and not givingus something we could be proud of.ldquoAs people began to use their collective voices, we have been able to get a special development off the ground.ldquoThe Oven is the flagship, and a blueprint to showwhat the people of Dumfries can do.The plans have been brewing since  when the townrsquos artist-led development trust, The Stove Network, carried out research to find out what the future of High Street might be and to ask local people what they wanted.ldquoThere were a number of issues, says Scott Mackay, manager of The Midsteeple Quarter.ldquoOne was ownership of High Street buildings. We discovereda lot are owned by absentee landlords who lived where, people notwith a vested interest in the town.ldquoFunds and investment companies had been buying up the buildings and renting out ground floors to national retail chains. Sometimes these buildings have two more floors, but they just lie empty.ldquoIt is the same at high streets up and down the country ndash every one had the same shops and streets had lost their local character.ldquoAs high streets contracted, there was out of town retail and internet shopping, so a lot of shop units were lying empty and the values of buildings dropped.With buildings which once carried a poundm price tag now valued at around half that, and vacant units with sky-high rents but no sign of new occupants, hopes grew that the townspeople could use community buy-out legislation to help them take over empty properties.Inspired by rural land community buy-outs in places such as Eigg, Assynt and Gigha, and driven by the townrsquos creative and artistic community, the Dumfries plan was designed to be Scotlandrsquos first ldquourban buy-out.Within weeks of its launch and a mock high street protest aimed at highlighting empty shops, the community benefit company had attracted hundreds ofpound shareholders eager tohave their say in forging a new-look town centre.Their plans were boosted two years ago, when Dumfries  Galloway Council agreed to hand over the former Bakersrsquo Oven building in an asset transfer deal that cost the group just pound.Itrsquos meant the group has not yet had to draw on community ownership legislation, while funds for The Ovenrsquos redevelopment have come from a iety of sources including the Regeneration Capital Grant Fund which is delivered in partnership between the Scottish Government and COSLA, and South Scotland Enterprise Fund.Planning approval forThe Oven is expected next month. Demolition work to the rear will begin later this year, with hopes it will be finished within  months.The organisation is also in the process of raising funds to buy two other units and has approached the owners of two others.Mr Mackay said the intention is to create a vibrant blend of retail, affordable housing, exhibition and arts space, with entertainment and food and drink outlets helping to transform the area into a bustling hub.ldquoAn obstacle for high streets for a long time has been a lsquoretail onlyrsquo or lsquoretail firstrsquo planning requirement, he added. ldquoIt meant that by pm everything in the High Street would be dead. We want the units to have dferent uses, so therersquos some le in the evening."That has to happen in high streets everywhere ndash therersquos not enough in the retail market for high streets to be what they once were.

title: snp-accused-massaging-figures-boost-rural-housing-progress
story: Homes built in the Birdiehouse area, in the south of the capital, have been labelled as ldquoaccessible rural under the Scottish Governmentrsquos affordable housing supply programme, along with homes in towns including Troon, Ayrshire, and Elgin, Moray.Calls have been made for rural communities to be given their fair share of affordable housing investment by the Scottish Government.Shelter Scotland has called on politicians drawing up manestos for next yearrsquos Scottish Parliament election to commit to building , affordable homes between  and  ndash with a capital investment programme ofpound. billion over the five-year period.A report drawn up by Shelter Scotland in collaboration with the Scottish Federation of Housing Associations and the Chartered Institute of Housing Scotland, has warned ldquomost house completions classied as rural by the Scottish Government were actually built in small towns or urban areas.:Shetland builder to get back on site as coronavirus lockdown easesRural Housing Scotlandfound that in -, only  per cent of ldquoso-called rural completions actually happened in areas of less than , inhabitants.RHS has now found that when the  homes built in suburban areas from Government statistics for -, only  out of , affordable homes built that year were in rural areas ndash meaning just % of the funding was allocated to rural areas.Derek Logie, chief executive of RHS, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government defines rural as settlements with fewer than , people, which encompasses everything from large villages in the Central Belt to a handful of houses on Unst. There is enough iety in there already and adding city suburbs and towns to the list of rural developments creates a  picture of investment in rural housing.Shelterrsquos research has acknowledged the Covid- pandemic will make the need for affordable housing even more important for a large number of people.It adds: ldquoThe virus has had a profound immediate impact on the role of housing in the lives of Scotlandrsquos population. ldquoFor many it has become the site of work and education for the first time, or the site of furlough. For many, concerns around affordability and tenure security have been introduced or enhanced. Housing has become a place of forced containment for the majority of the population. Covid- has highlighted the signicance of every household having access to high quality and affordable housing.Mr Logie has backed the calls for further investment to be handed over to support affordable housing projects.:Scotlandrsquos lsquourban buy-outrsquo could be blueprint for townsShadow communities secretary Graham Simpson said: ldquoThis looks very much like the Government has been massaging some figures to make their record on affordable rural housing look better. It was well known that the SNP were on course to miss their affordable housing by some measure across the board. These kinds of shenanigans show even they are aware of that fact.A Government spokesman said: ldquoThe Government uses the six-fold urban rural classication when categorising homes delivered through the affordable housing programme , basedon information provided by AHSP grant applicants.ldquoWe recognise that good quality, affordable housing is essential tohelp attract and retain people in Scotlandrsquos rural and island communities. Our affordable housing supply programme, which includes the rural and islands housing funds, provides flexible solutions for the delivery of more affordable homes for rent or purchase in rural and island areas.ldquoWe have committed more than pound.bn in affordable housing over this parliamentary term.

title: we-love-lockdown-stranded-international-students
story: If itrsquos not his music, itrsquos -year-old Chinese student Evan Ren chatting online to his friends or parents , miles away in Beijing, talking to teachers at his Edinburgh boarding school about lessons or playing a game on his laptop.Theyrsquore the sounds of a teenager busying himself as best he can. Andfor the retired couple who have unexpectedly opened their home to him for what could be the best part of an entire year, they have made lockdown a little bit more bearable.At a time when some parents may be struggling with pent up angst-ridden teens during lockdown, Shirley and Alanthe Firths, and other host families who have stepped in to help as international boarding school students faced uncertainty, have found surprising benefits to looking after someone rsquos child.ldquoI think wersquove got the best end of the deal, says Mrs Firth. ldquoWe have had company and having a young person in the house makes you think about doing dferent things, whereas we might just have sat in front of the television.Both in their early s, with their own five children who are now adults and all but one living hundreds of miles away, the retired couple might have faced a quiet and possibly boring few months of lockdown at home.Instead, as the crisis evolved and a hectic dash began to figure out how to either repatriate hundreds of international students studying at Scottish boarding schools or find them somewhere to stay, the pair offered help.Now, with Evan living in their home in Tranent, near Edinburgh, and quarantine restrictions making it pointless for him to even consider travelling home to China for summer, the couple face looking after their international visitor until at least September when Merchiston Castle School is expected to reopen ndash and possibly until Christmas.It may sound daunting to suddenly find yourself looking after someone rsquos teenager when yoursquore in your twilight years, but, the couple insist it could not have worked out better.ldquoEvan walks the dog either with me or my husband once a day to get exercise and fresh air, we sit in the garden, wersquove had a barbecue and we play games, says Mrs Firth.ldquoEvan plays the French horn very well. We watch television and wersquove been learning about China. Hersquos interesting, his English is excellentand hersquos travelled a lot.And, she adds, there has been another unanticipated benefit.ldquoOne of my sons organises an online quiz that we do on Zoom on Sunday evening, says Shirley. ldquoEvan has been a real help when questions come up to do with music or things that we donrsquot know the answer to ndash he usually does.The couple have opened their home to international students at weekends and half-term holidays when boarding school accommodation closes down for the past three years.Normally, however, they would host children for only a few weeks at a time.However, as the pandemic emerged and boarding schools prepared to close, an urgent rush began to find routes home for about , international pupils in Scottish schools.Edinburgh-based Academic Families, an internationalorganisation that organises the boarding and care of children who come to Scotlandrsquos most exclusive schools from other countries, helped almost  pupilshome.In some cases, pupils ndash some just years old ndash faced daunting journeys of thousands of miles, wearing PPEon flights and often involving several stops to reach their final destination.In all, Academic Families ed children to  dferent countries. Other similarorganisations also faced a rush to organise international transport for hundreds of students, while some parents paid eye-watering bills for last-minute flights.ldquoFamilies have been absolute troopers, says Lorna Clayton, of Academic Families. ldquoThey have stepped into the breech, they didnrsquot know what was going to happen, how long things were going to continue.Yoko Nakano, , a student at Fettes College in Edinburgh, also opted to stay in Scotland rather than travel home to Tokyo. She is now staying with Margaret and Brian Dickson in Dollar, Clackmannanshire.Yoko Nakano, , a student at Fettes College in Edinburgh, opted to stay in Scotland rather than travel home to Tokyo. She is now staying with Margaret and Brian Dickson in their home in Dollar, Clackmannanshire.ldquoHaving her here during this time has enhance our lives and given dimension to our days, says Margaret, .ldquoShe is very quick to laugh, she is funny and smiles a lot. "She is a delight to be with.ldquoHaving her here has been good for me, itrsquos made me think about catering more than I would normally do and has given me more structure at a time when normal things that I would do arenrsquot happening.Yoko, one of a group of eight students from Japan studying at Fettes as part of a two-year scholarship aimed at paving their route to elite universities opted to remain in Scotland in order to improve her English and learn more about the UK.She will spend summer with the couple before ing to school in Edinburgh in September.ldquoI thought I might have to go back, so I am happy now, she says. ldquoI like it here, the air is fresh, itrsquos quiet and peaceful. Itrsquos dferent from Tokyo. ldquoI feel like Irsquom part of their family.ldquoHaving her here during has enhanced our lives and given dimension to our days, says Mrs Dickson, .ldquoShe is very quick to laugh, is funny and smiles a lot. She is a delight to be with. Having her here has been good for me, itrsquos made me think about catering more than I would normally.Yoko, one of a group of eight students from Japan studying at Fettes as part of a two-year scholarship aimed at paving their route to elite universities opted to remain in Scotland to improve her English and learn more about the UK.She will spend summer with the couple before ing to school in Edinburgh in September.

title: letters-four-nations-approach-proved-mistake
story: As I stated in a previous letter, the devolved administrations were ldquodaft to go along with the ldquofour nations approach, where London was setting policy based on the SAGE advice where they were not allowed to ask direct questions.I was first in these Letters Pages to suggest an inquiry would be required to learn lessons. I hope we get the entire truth of this pandemic, herd immunity and the reasons for the languid approach of the British state, but I doubt it. We get a glimpse of Westminster control-freakery with the side-lining of Englandrsquos Chief Nursing Officer Ruth May and Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jonathon Van Tam, and the prevention of others from answering pertinent questions. This, for political, not scientic or health reasons. Everyone has questions to answer, but Westminster is, by far, the most culpable.G R Weir, Ochiltree.THE ldquoevidence Peter Russell assembles for his claim that the Covid- ldquobuck stops with the Scottish Government has more holes than a piece of Emmental cheese.Showing ldquohow and when the Scottish Government was overruled on the issues of lockdown and quarantine may be interesting, but the fact is that their powers are not adequate to accomplish most of what Mr Russell condemns them for not doing.Mr Russell forgets how Lord McConnell, while still First Minister, was slapped down by the Home Office for suggesting that post-graduate students be allowed to remain for a couple of years after their course had completed. Immigration is reserved to Westminster, so the First Minister had no powers to close Scotlandrsquos borders and any suggestion or implication to the contrary is misleading.As far as the lockdown is concerned,put in place before Westminsterrsquos decision, does Mr Russell not consider it probable to the point of near certainty that, their powers over public health notwithstanding, national chains of shops would have gone to court to test the power of the First Minister to close their Scottish branches as excessive, particularly when Westminster had not done the same Moreover, lockdown would mean many employees having no income, but being non-sovereign, and unlike Rishi Sunak, unable to drop a line to Andrew Barclay at the Bank of England asking him to print more money to support the furlough scheme that has put in place a floor for the economy, where was the First Minister to secure the resources to do this  This is why the Nicola Sturgeon and theFirst Minister of Wales have written to the Chancellor asking that the furlough scheme be extended to suit the pace at which the dferent nations leave lockdown.Despite Mr Russellrsquos imaginative demands to see evidence of the Scottish Government taking its own alternative position, none of this challenges Bismarckrsquos view that ldquopolitics is the art of the possible and that what was possible was very much in the gt of the Westminster Government. Yes, public health is devolved, but the above are not. As the UK Government has learned in its approach to the EU, cherry-picking is not possible.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.STRUAN Stevensonrsquos claim that the coronavirus has claimed two-thirds of the lives that are lost on British roads every yearcannot go unchallenged. As soon as I read those words I thought, that cannot be right, so I decided to do some research.The most up to date figures I was able to find were from . The website for Brake, the road safety charity claims that , people were killed on British roads in . The UK Governmentrsquos own website states that the figure was , and gives a provisional estimate for the year ending June  of ,.We can all make mistakes of course, but to quote figures so wildly far off the mark is irresponsible.David Clark, Tarbolton.I AM a -year-old retired doctor with ongoing cancer, living in the Scottish Borders. I wrote to my MP, John Lamont, on March , nine days before lockdown, strongly supporting the open letter  British scientists had sent that day urging immediate lockdown. I asked my MP to urge the Government to implement immediate social distancing measures. He replied on March : ldquoI strongly believe the British Government is correct to follow what our own advisors tell us. I was so troubled I emailed him on March  and again on March  emphasising the fact that every day of delay was allowing more viral spread, meaning overwhelmed NHS doctors and nurses would soon be making agonising treatment decisions.Mr Lamont believes that local voices should be heard "at the highest levels" and is diligent with correspondence. I have asked him repeatedly whether he acted on my March emails. Unfortunately, he declines to answer that question, instead replying tersely on June : ldquoI point out again, the decision on when and how to impose lockdown restrictions here in Scotland is the responsibility of the Scottish Government. Do you dispute that Irsquove been shaken by such a reply from my elected representative. It leaves me feeling more vulnerable and totally unrepresented by the MP who, in mid-March, I asked three times to forward on to Westminster my urgent and relevant health concerns regarding all UK citizens.Earlier action by Boris Johnson in March would have made such a dference. On March  both Denmark and UK had a similar number of recorded cases of coronavirus,  and  cases respectively. On March  Denmark locked down. UK allowed business to continue as usual and inexplicably stopped all virus testing in the community on March  despite WHO advice to "Test. Test. Test." Denmark is now out of lockdown with a Covid death rate of  per million population. UK has an exhausted care system, a death rate of  per million, and worryingly high rates of new infection as we struggle to emerge from lockdown. It is a tragedy that could have been avoidedMr Johnson had listened to all scientic advice in March.Dr Mary Gillies, Selkirk.ANDY Maciverwrites that we should have some empathy with our senior politicians as they have to make very dficult decisions at this time.Indeed they do have very dficult choices and one of the easiest for Mr Johnson to make was to sack Dominic Cummings for taking us all as fools for driving to Barnard Castle to check his eyesight. Maybe he needed them checked to read his marriage certicate. Oh yes, it was that date.Funny how the Government and Mr Johnsonrsquos popularity has plummeted since making that choice.Sorry Mr Maciver, any sympathy I had for Mr Johnson has disappeared. He is not a leader, he continues to wing his policies.Willie Towers, Alford.ANDY Maciver urges us to give our leaders our support, as human beings in the same boat as we all are, but with much greater responsibilities than most of us, instead of heaping opprobrium on them.Hes got a good foundation for this attitude. Theres a biblical mandate for all of us ndash believers of whatever persuasion and none ndash o honour those in authority and to pray for them. .Were responsible for having put these men and women in a position of authority over us by our votes. We need to continue our duty by supporting them and doing so, as Mr Maciver writes, not by agreeing with everything they say or do but by recognising the responsibility that lies on their shoulders.David Kennedy, Glasgow G.Read more: Letters: It should be clear that the buck rests with the Scottish Government

title: letters-british-state-pay-reparations
story: After Bannockburn, nothing changed in the misery ordinary folk suffered at the hands of the barons, with their right to "pit and gallows". But, whatever truth Johnston lays bare about Bruce ndash dferent from the story book tale ndash the consequence of his self-interest was to stamp forever on our national le, the idea of Scotland independent from England. Wrecking his statue and memorial doesnrsquot alter history one jot, or erase him from it as one of the most important figures in our nationrsquos narrative. Let the man be.Where does the logic of the demolition crew stop  It cannot be at tearing down mere blocks of stone, which can speak,they do, only from one spot. Of far greater importance are written works still in wide circulation: books, plays and poems. If statutes are to fall, why are written works, with offensive content ignored, and not ceremoniously burned in great piles  Are Shakespeare, Dickens, Kipling, Burns, and many more, all to be eliminated  If not, why not  It is impossible to hump statues around, but not books, or plays. The only dference in principle between statues and books, is that the latter are far more widespread and thus more influential on human thought and action.There is a far better way for the Black Lives Matter movement to create the change needed. Demand reparations from the British state, which includes Scotland, for the evil done by the slave trade. Slavery was abolished by a combination of moral pressure and money. The slave owners received compensation for loss of "property" at todayrsquos equivalent of pound billion. The slaves got nothing.Adequate reparations is more than a gesture to correct a historical wrong. A large reparations fund should be run by the minorities whose ancestors were exploited. They, better than anyone , know what needs to be done to build their institutional and societal strengths, and so help create a country where respect and equality are the birth right of everyone. It is surely more productive to pursue reparations that can have a long term practical, beneficial effect for people of colour, than toppling Henry Dundas.Jim Sillars, Edinburgh EH.EVER the opportunist, Nicola Sturgeon says her Government will lead the debate about street names and statues in Scotland. She is an extremely intelligent woman brought up in the west of Scotland, who, like me and many others, will have always been aware that hugely financially successful Glasgow merchants, like those in Bristol and Liverpool, not only traded in cotton, sugar and tobacco but also slaves. It would be cynical of me to suggest that raising the subject now may be because she sees a few more votes from that cause.However,she is now to become a paragon of virtue about things in the past, how about removing statues and tributes to Robert the Bruce who gained the Scottish crown by cold-blooded murder  Pigs might fly.Duncan Sooman, Milngavie.

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  George Square needs to be completely overhauled - here   s why
story: The new station completely transforms the look and feel of this part of town. What a shame, then, about the second thing I couldnrsquot help noticing: how drab and disappointing George Square remains.Granted, the grim sight of loyalist protesters wrapped in Union flags ldquoprotecting the statues and Cenotaph didnrsquot help. But even without their isive presence the cityrsquos historic square is a let-down, visually, socially and culturally, a frustrating waste of urban space that could and should be far better utilised.Where other European squares create buzz and atmosphere with year-round arts, culture, food and shopping attracting locals and visitors, George Square is dreary and uninspiring: a few trees, some benches and a clutch of dull, predictable th-century statues ndash ldquogreat men and Queen Victoria ndash that few feel any kinship with. The only part of the square that has any real purpose and meaning is the Cenotaph.The idea that George Square is in serious need of a makeover is nothing new, of course, and there have been ious  dawns and broken promises over the years, not least the outrageous fiasco of  ndash remember that  ndash which wasted huge amounts of public money and goodwill alike. But the two defining events of  - coronavirus and the Black Lives Matter protests -offer Glasgow the best opportunity in a generation to finally get this right and transform George Square into the vibrant civic centre Glaswegians deserve.Letrsquos start with the pandemic, which will continue to damage the economic and social pull of town and city centres. As lockdown restrictions are gradually lted we will grasp a new reality ndash fewer shops, restaurants, bars and cultural attractions than before, with those that do re-open unable to work at full capacity for now. Answers to the sort of questions around attracting people to city centres that were already stumping businesses, planners and local authorities even before coronavirus hit have become all the more pressing.Thatrsquos where a proper revamp of George Square comes in, a key step forward in boosting Glasgowrsquos economy and cultural capital in the wake of the pandemic. What should the square contain  That would be for citizens to decide, but herersquos a few quick ideas that presume an eventual end to social distancing: an ampitheatre for live music, theatre and comedy, proper seating, pop-up pods for community groups, a food and craft market, arts and exhibition space, murals, a garden and childrenrsquos play area.As for the fate of the statues, again, it would be for the people to decide whether they still have a place in this new urban realm. Not that we would want to forget our past, of course. But surely we can find new and more creative ways to confront, commemorate and celebrate it, taking in voices that were previously ignored ndash women, ethnic minorities, working class people, gay people, the disabled ndash reflecting the ersity of our city as it is now.Rather than an expensive international competition for designs ndash letrsquos learn from  ndash a three-month public consultation could be held, and a  of local architects, planners, artists, businesspeople and community groups convened to create perhaps three dferent plans, which would then be voted on by the people of Glasgow. Granted, such an ambitious revamp wouldnrsquot be easy to fund in the dficult years ahead, but with a crucial economic and culturalat stake, it should be prioritised. Surely a mixture of public, private and philanthropic funding could be sourced Glasgow City Council has already started the conversation that could make all this happen, by bringing forward the pedestrianisation of George Square and suspending a third of city centre parking bays to make room for walkers and cyclists.I would urge council leader Susan Aitken and her team to think bigger. A commitment to redesign George Square would offer an exciting, positive and inclusive focus for Glaswegians in the tough months ahead. The end result could be what Glasgow has been crying out for for a generation: a proud and modern civic centrepiece that is worthy of our great city, a place that excites, entertains, and educates, that makes us feel part of something bigger. Wersquove never needed it more.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: home-dna-kits-shed-light-different-covid-19-impacts-scots-researchers-say
story: Scientists are asking people who have used DNA services, such as Ancestry DNA, FTDNA and andMe, to join a study which aims to identy key genes involved in the bodyrsquos response to the infection.They believe understanding the effect genes have on susceptibility to Covid- could aid efforts to tackle the pandemic and help combat future disease outbreaks.More than  million people worldwide have used genetic testing services and researchers are now urging them to share their DNA data to speed up discoveries that could help fight the virus.Jim Wilson, professor of human genetics and co-leader the study, said: ldquoSome people suffer no ill effects from coronavirus infection, yet others require intensive care.:Agenda: Reason, not fear, should have dictated the Covid- responseldquoWe need to identy the genes causing this susceptibility, so we can understand the biology of the virus and hence develop better drugs to fight it.Albert Tenesa, professor of quantitative genetics and co-leader, added: ldquoTime is of the essence.ldquoTo identy the genes that explain why some people get very sick from coronavirus and others donrsquot, we need the solidarity of a large proportion of people from dferent countries who can share their DNA testing results with us.ldquoIn this case, size really matters.The team aims to identy genes that influence the risk of developing Covid- and those that affect disease severity, by comparing volunteersrsquo symptoms, or lack of them, with their DNA.Those taking part in the University of Edinburgh study, called Coronagenes, will complete online questionnaires about their health, lestyle and any symptoms they have experienced, such as fever or a persistent cough.:Scotland facing worst downturn in modern times amid coronavirus crisisUpdating the survey before, during and after infection will help scientists detect any patterns that might indicate how the virus progresses.Researchers also aim to analyse the long-term health consequences of infection and self-isolation.To volunteer for the study visit ed.ac.uk coronagenes.

title: easyjet-flight-lands-glasgow-marking-airlines-first-journey-since-lockdown-began
story: The flight left Gatwick airport at am and landed in Glasgow International Airport at around .am.It is the first trip from the airline since March , when the country began to shut down due to the coronavirus crisis.EasyJetrsquos boss has insisted he would ldquofeel % safe on packed planes.:easyJet admits nine million customers have been hackedChief executive Johan Lundgren told the PA news agency that the Luton-based carrier took guidance from international regulators to develop an enhanced safety and hygiene regime ahead of its resumption of flights on Monday.Director of Flight Operations Captain David Morgan and Captain Kate McWilliams in the cockpit of easyJet flight EZY. Credit: PAPassengers and crew are required to wear masks, aircraft are regularly deep-cleaned, and disinfection wipes and hand sanitiser are being made available.Mr Lundgren said not operating a single flight in nearly three months has been ldquodevastating, and the airline is ldquosuper-excited toto the skies.He will travel on his first easyJet flight after the restart on Wednesday.Askedhe would be anxious about his healththe plane is full, he replied: ldquoI would feel % safe.ldquoThe recommendations that wersquove implemented have been defined together with international regulators Easa , ICAO , the CAAand also our own companyrsquos medical doctors and expertise.The Airbus Aneo ndash easyJetrsquos largest aircraft ndash can seat  passengers.:EasyJet to resume flights from Scotland from next month with new safety measures in placeDespite the -day quarantine policy and current travel restrictions imposed in the UK, Mr Lundgren said he believed summer holidays will be possible.He went on: ldquoWe would hope and would be really looking forward to restrictions being either lted, or air bridges put in place where it made sense to do so, allowing UK customers as well as people in the rest of Europe to be able to go on a holiday.EasyJetrsquos initial schedule involves mainly domestic flying in the UK and France.The airline will ramp up its operations in the coming weeks.

title: nicola-sturgeon-speaks-joy-visits-parents-first-time-three-months
story: Nicola Sturgeon revealed earlier this month that she did not visit her family in North Ayrshire in the first weekend of easing lockdown restrictions in Scotland.She admitted that she did not want to add to the numbers out on the road who would be making similar journeys as the country entered Phase  in the last few weeks.:Nicola Sturgeon reveals she did not visit family over first weekend of easing lockdownIn a special Covid- interview airing across the HitsRadioNetwork on June , Ms Sturgeon jokingly hoped her mother would be able to hear the reasons behind not visiting.Now, the First Minister has finally paid a visit to her parents - and said that she missed them. style" background:#FFF border: border-radius:px box-shadow:  px  rgba, px px  rgba margin:  auto max-width:px padding: width:.% width:-webkit-calc width: auto" display:block height:px margin: auto -px position:relative top:-px width:px"LoadingIn an Instagram post, Ms Sturgeon shared an image of the pair in their back garden.She wrote: "Had a physically distanced garden visit to my mum and dad this evening - the first time Irsquove seen them in  months."Irsquove missed them.":Nicola Sturgeon desperate to hug parents after lockdown is overMs Sturgeon also shared an image of a tree, which she says was bought for her father as a Fathers Day gt almost  years ago.In the Hits Radio interview, she said: ldquoI think itrsquos fair to say what wersquove all been living through in the past couple of months is putting all sorts of things in perspective.ldquoThe kind of things that used to wind me up and the things that maybe used to worry me and the things that I would get upset about just donrsquot feel as important anymore."
